reviews.review:
Its free. avoid the tact and crowds visit during a "white night". Wonderful open square that is free to view the marvel of the winter palce. It does tend to get a little windy at times.
Best time to view is during the white nights in high summer.not a soul around
Grand Entrance to The Hermitage. This grand space is a fitting entrance to The Hermitage. Inaccessible to vehicles it is very safe to wander around.

A once in a lifetime experience. This is the world's treasure trove. I recommend at least three to four days set aside just for the Winter Palace and at least one day for each of Peterhof and the Summer Palace.

truly impressive. and even in October wildly cold. The square itself is huge, such a grand scale is exciting all on its own. The buildings, too are almost majestic, but on an ordinary day in early October, the cold wind blew fiercely and it felt like the Steppes of Central Asia. Even that was impressive. Groups gather at the column in the center to meet before tours, a freezing choice. Within one of the pictured green buildings is a new, decidedly unfinished museum (yes, built within the original structure) housing the recently "revealed" French impressionist paintings brought from Germany just after WWII. Fifty years in storage, they are now being shown, previously in traveling exhibitions, now in this truly inconvenient new space. Fewer than half of the collection are on exhibition currently.

Nice place on a nice day. Don't get too over excited on this one. It was a nice place on a sunny day, there were horse drawn carriages and lovely surroundings. The down side was nowhere to sit, constantly being badgered by people selling tourist tat and, as I understand it, pickpockets are in full force when it is busy.Enjoy, but don't stay too long as there are many things worth seeing in St Petersburg

Magnificent . Peter the first decided that cities had to be designed on a massive and grand scale. Grandeur and space was the order of the day. He also could things that he saw ion his travels in Europe and this is a classic example of his work. A massive square on a scale of Place de la Concorde in Paris but with much more impressive buildings bordering the square with no cars allowed. Very impressive especially at night

Great but big crowds mid morning til late afternoon. Great place to visit and it has to be on your must do list. However the square is absolutely full of large travel groups and it is hard to get a photo without lots of other tourists in the shots.

Walk-bye attraction. The palace square is in front of the Eremitage museum and is situated between the Winter palace and the General Staff building, with the Alexander Column in the center which was raised raised after the victory of Russia over Napoleon's France in 1834. Built of one single piece of red granite, weighing 661 tons it was erected with the help of 3'000 men in less than two hours.

Great square. This is a big square that has the Hermitage on one side and the Winter Palace on the other side. When you stand in the middle, you get a sense of how big the tsars thought. Everything was grandiose in size and character.It is the main square in St Petersburg. In the middle of the square is the Alexander Column which is about 50 metres high.
Must visit spot in Saint Petersburg. It is a must visit spot in Saint Petersburg. There are many attractions in this area. The photo is nice even day time or night time.

huge area , wonderful regal horse drawn carraiges available to take a ride. A massive big square, the carraiges and horses are stunning. Artists also selling their paintings. A great place to relax as it is so vast , there is no tourist crush
Crowded. Beautiful square with a wonderful view of the winter palace. A large monument stands in the center of the square. Be prepared though as the crowds are always and large.
Imposing space.. Wonderful large square and imposing monument with great views of the Hermitage/Winter Palace on one side and arcade opposite.

Great place to stroll. The place in front of the palace is a great place to hang out, especially when the sun is out. If you hope to walk around with a coffee or an icecream, plan ahead as no vendors or stores were to be found when I was there.
Most popular and crowded. Be aware it's usually full of people. The most beautiful time to visit it when it's a heavy rain. Really cool, empty, the best pictures will be taken!

Simply awesome . A majestic square surrounded by beautiful buildings. The monument in the center is a huge granite column with an angel on top. I believe the column is free standing and built from one granite piece. Certainly a must see.

Circling the Square. Near the end of Nevsky Prospekt and Palace Bridge, this incredibly huge and open plaza separates world-class Winter Palace and Hermitage museums. It is believed to be Europe’s largest public square. At the heart of the Square is the world’s largest single-stone monolith, combined with a bronze angel statue to be 156 feet tall. Throngs of tourist and locals gather here, most to stand in endless lines for admission to Hermitage Museum, which I advise a guided tour and as soon as the doors open. In the afternoon, the crowds are unfathomable. Beware of pickpockets approaching tourists gawking at the magnificence of the two museums and the world’s largest single-stone column. There’s no cost to visit this site, so why not enjoy two impressive palaces and outdoor art?
I Very pretty. Outdoor market vendors, bustling courtyard with street performers, stunning architecture, it's was like something out of a movie!
Very pretty. This area is really amazing - some great buildings and even neat carriages outside. I would highly recommend walking around this area and seeing all the nice architecture!
Impressive size. Some interesting facts to be had here and would recommend a guide for details. Don'd forget to walk down the side streets.

Largest Central Square in Europe. With the Winter Palace on one side and the giant General Staff building on the other this is a huge central square. Alexander's column in the middle of the square is the starting point for the free walking tour in several brochures. There are horse and carriage rides available and you can walk through the huge Triumphal Arch to get to the central end of Nevsky Prospeckt. Our guide told us that the whole square and the buildings are illuminated at night but we were too tired to come back later.
Beautiful place!. This place is amazing and full of history! it is a must during your visit! Standing in the middle of two gigantic palaces is unique!
Be amazed at how big the square is.. This is a nice place, not good when cold, but lovely on a June evening. Enjoy the moment and take in the history.

Huuuge square. To really experience the majesty of this place, go there by night. It is truly impressive. The buildings are covered in yellow light, so you can take some cool pictures as well. During the day, the square is noisy and might be overcrowded, but around 12 AM, you can really enjoy the silence and the greatness of this place.

Gigantic Square!. This was an enormous square full of people but you could still find your space here. It's clean and full of horses and birds. There were Peter and Catharina the Great walking around taking photos with tourists and making money, it's fine coz they didn't force you to take the photo with them anyway, plus they're quite friendly that you could even have a chat with them! The free walking tour also started here at the Alexander's column in the middle of the square. In midday, this square was spectacular and it's even more beautiful at night when all the light turned on. So try to be here at both time. :-)

outdoor concert venue. vast open square fronted by winter palace and general stafff building, and the start of millionaires row, lots more palaces two concerts were taking place during our visit, not really our thing.
Beautiful. A place where u can spend an entire day admiring the architecture and beauty. A museam beside is a great place to explore
Love this place. The day was sunny and warm, the surroundings were fabulous and there were tourists everywhere. But we loved it.

Elegant Palace Square. The beauty and elegance of the Palace square remains with us. The light pastel color left an impressionIt was not crowded in October. Nice weather. Clean and immaculate square, We enjoyed the sight
Must see. An amazing place to visited whenever you are at St. Petersburg huge palace and many things to visit at the same time
Enjoyed the Palace!. enjoyed seeing the site, meeting the people, going into the palace was amazing! Was surprised by the amount of riches the zar and his family had!
superb. amazing place connecting the nevsky prospect,must visit,great sight for pictures.very crowded!!shouldn't be missed on your trip.

Superb is the word to describe . Wow.. What a place to visit and take memories in pictures. The Beauty of construction and high class and cleanness makes the place for beautiful and given a pleasure to be there

Beautiful but difficult to get photos without obstructions. You will either have to come here very early before the tourists to get the best photos or after the museums close so the buses are not in your photos.
Huge square. We were there for a brief sunny glimpse at the splendor of Catherine's Palace and the gate. It was worth a visit to get a sense for the size and feel of some of these places. Very grand.
Amazing square. Palace Square (Dvortsovaya Ploshchad) is amazing. You must go there and see beautiful buildings around it. Colorful place and freedom atmosphere.
Very beautiful. Very beautiful, lots of air and space. You can go around in an old fashioned carriage, from time to time there are different concerts.
Have to go!. Must see, outside the Hemitage and admire the sheer size of this square, we had beautiful weather which made the day even more special

Nice Square. It is a pretty huge square in which the access to Winter Place and General Stuff Building is located. It offers the chance to take nice pictures of both buildings and the size of the square surely amplify their magnificence.

History change..... You feel the history on this place...You can argue, what is right and what is wrong, but what is happened on this Ploshad, can not be forgotten and it is definitely changed the course of history
one day visit of spectacular places. Huge square, magnificent in many ways, Needs more explanation of its history and significance. only limited resources used to inform the traveling public

Enormous - sized for palaces, parades, and performances. This is not a typical European civic/market square but is instead an enormous space custom built to be a parade ground for the palace. That said, it is completely worth a visit and is fascinating and beautiful in it's own right. We walked and wandered and took a few photos before heading off for lunch.Plus it's right outside the Hermitage on the way to whatever you are seeing next so you need to travel through it anyway. Just don't be disappointed by the lack of cafes and shops - those are over on Nevsky Prospekt.
Great space with energy night and day. Good photos before the crowds arrive by 9am. Often good music at night fills the huge square. Opposite is the Staff Building which is also a lovely building.

The Heart of St. Petersburg....ITS A MUST. DO NOT LEAVE WITHOUT A VISIT. The Red Square of the north but bigger.. Palace Square is next to the Neva River at one end of Nevsky Prospect and is the place to be seen. IT IS ENORMOUS AS WELL AS SPECTACULAR which is just as well as it includes the ICONIC HERMITAGE MUSEUM, the beautiful WINTER PALACE, the COLUMN TO TSAR ALEXANDER, the tribute to the NAPOLEONIC CAMPAIGN and the General Administration Building which look palatial anyway. Opposite the Square, is the ADMIRALTY building which is equally impressive.TIP...take care with your belongings as this is where pickpockets are about AND do not take photos of the scanty -clad red uniformed blondes unless you are prepared topay them.
Meh. There is not much to see in the square, so that is why I didn't give it much more of a better review. Seen one square, you have seen them all.
Very impressive. One of the most impressive squares in europe. Very impressive place to see and walk through. The winter palace and the general staff headquarters make the place really magnificent.
Huge square!. Palace square is very impressive.. It's huge! and surrounded on all sides by grand old palaces. You may see old-fashioned carriages offering rides here also.

Visit twice - in the morning/afternoon and in the evening. Amazing place asks for whirling or at least 360 degree photo/video to enjoy all architectural masterpieces around the square. but do come in the evening as well, as street musicians perform in various spots of the square. Feel the rhythm of St Pete (it's rock mostly :))
Nice square. Nice square outside the Winter Palace. I think they said it was the fourth largest in Europe. Gather here to go into the palace but taking a tour lets you in earlier from the other side
Place of interest to visit. . It is good to look and walk through and to take some wonderful photos from of the historic buildings .

A must-visit. There's not much to say about this square that hasn't already been said, but I have to stress the need to designate some time to simply be there. I think a lot of people "see" it on their way into the Hermitage, but you should give yourself some time to walk the perimeter, take a look at the central column, and even do some people-watching. There are often couples dressed in beautiful historical costumes roaming the square (who will take a picture with you for a moderate fee).
Very big.. A great square. I did not realise how big this area was. It is good to just look around you and walk around and see it from different angles.

Palpable Sense of History. This is the square in front of the Winter Palace/Hermitage on one side and two semi-circular yellow buildings across, one of them housing more Hermitage treasures and the other, military offices. This was center stage for the 1905 revolt and a lot of the action for the 1917 revolution. Standing in this overwhelming square gives you a sense of all that happened there during pivotal moments in Russian history. Drop dead gorgeous.

Wonderful space!. The scale of the palace square is just awesome. Surrounded by impressive historical buildings and built around an incredible central column (which stands erect only by gravity!), it's a wonderful space to walk/stand/sit, take photos, chat. A must see!
Absolutely stunning. This place will make you feel you are back in the days of the Czar, with horse-drawn carriages and people walking around. It is simply beautiful.
Visist Palace square. Located in the heart of St Petersburg and an easy place to visit. Worth the effort. I went early in the morning to photograph the area and avoided the crowds.

Excellent spots to take photos. A good place to stop by for photo taking before you enter the Hermitage Museum. You can capture the Winter Palace, the General Staff Building (the yellowish building in half moon lay out) and the Alexander Column.

Great place. This place is surrounded by the Hermitage and other impressive buildings from Tsar time. Huge column in the center. The column is made in one marble block, making it even more impressive!

Huge "square" (although rectangular in size) in front of the Winter Palace. Massive open space in front of the Winter Palace (now the Hermitage museum) which was the official residence of the Czar's family. The Palace was built on the bank of the Neva River and is impressive from both view points. The square itself has a long history of protests, violence and grand demonstrations of power.

Vast Space. The beauty of the buildings are there to see but to stand in this vast space is awe inspiring. Wherever you look it is magnificent; you feel as if you are in a bygone age. Take your time and enjoy the sights.

Walking in history at its best. Standing in the Square and looking around you is a delight - the Winter Palace on a sunny day with the sun glinting off the golden crown is remarkable. But it is only when you apply the history to the things you are looking at, that the Square comes to life and bores into your soul. Read up on Russian history, or do a guided walking tour to fully appreciate.

Huge open space next to the Winter Palace. We visited the Palace Square on a rather grey day, so the colours in the photograph are somewhat muted. The Winter Palace / Hermitage museum is at one side of the square and opposite is the large gateway with similar statues to those on top of the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin.

History Overload. This place has so much preserved, amazing. It would take someone hundred of years to read every detail what is inside. overall, Very pack with history. Well preserved items of history.

What a country.... What a square! Impressive. Interesting to note that on one ide is the Hermitage Museum (Winter Palace) and the other side is the Russian military headquarters. I don't suppose that you are allowed in there though. Done on a grand scale....

way too many. st peter cant stop at a point, each place will give you a wow factor.another must see site at the great city, which need a lotttttttttttt of your time to explore.Enjoy another must see site

Immense square. Such a huge area. Rivals Tiananmen Square in Beijing for vastness. These large gathering areas are non existent in our North American cities and it gives one the opportunity to feel what it might have been like to experience Russia a hundred years ago.

Historical heart of St. Petersburg. Palace Square or Dvortsovaya Ploshchad as locals call it is the historical heart of St.Petersburg: the Hermitage, Stella devotrd to Alexander I, St. Isaac Cathedral, Nevsky Prospect, Neva River, Bronze Horseman, Admiralty - big bulk of main city attractions are based on Palace Square or very close by. It's a beautiful place for walking during sunny weather. A lot of souvenirs shops, cafes, historical sites makes this place the starting point for the city visitors.

That's not a square.......... What a monster yet in proportion. The near centre column looks almost as if it could fall but won't. The inter-play between the green of the Winter Palace and the cream of the General Staff Building create some sort of expectation as to the contents of each of them. The size of this square is much bigger than Red Square in Moscow. The Square is not enclosed so there is massive amounts of space and sky.
beautiful square. One of the free attractions and a great place to start touring the city centre. The uniformity is beautiful, such an overwhelming feeling standing there.
Awesome. It exhales power. One of the best Saint Petersburg areas, very close to the main monuments. Impressive in the sunset. Usually visited together with the Hermitage.

Great photo opportunity. Such a fine square bound by spectacular buildings. Imagine yourself back to the 18th century. Enjoy walking around taking in the size of the Hermitage. If you feel so inclined you can go round in a "Cinderella" carriage or on a segway.

A beautiful place to visit. This is a lovely place to visit whilst in St Petersburg. The building and grounds afford many photo opportunities and the internal rooms are exquisite. Be warned that the queues can be very long so it's best to go on an organised tour.
A good place to take photos. A good place to take some photos while waiting for the entrance of the palace. Some stands sell breads, drinks and souvenirs nearby.
Beautiful view. Visit the palace square during the day and during the night. It changes a lot. Often you will find live music there and lots of people. It is lovely!
Lively at night. This place takes on a different character at night with street performers and young people. We were surprised and delighted by this as we left the nearby Nep restaurant.

Lovely. Prior to the Hermitage, we stopped at Palace Square which is interesting and historic, of course. If you're planning to see the Hermitage, you will definitely see Palace Square and be happy you did so.
amazing place. You can combine the visit of the Hermitage with a visit of the Palace squre . perfect place to take a pictures for the memories

Massive area with a lot happening. We were able to catch a military display by the Russian Military. It was awesome. Also a few people dressed up wanting to take photos and horse and carriages available for rent.

When real estate was cheap. Palace Square is enormous! The hardest part is finding a place or time to get a photo without hundreds of people in the background. I spent an hour photo-shopping people out of our portraits. Overhead wires too seem to be everywhere. Pictures do not show the vastness of the place.

Attractive meeting point. This large square is situated in front of the Hermitage museum in the Winter Palace. The other buildings around the perimeter are also attractive. There are a small number of horse drawn carriages you can ride in and a good number of small stalls where you can buy touristy souvenirs and snacks (including an excellent hot dog and some very good ice cream).I wouldn't make a special trip to go there but I wouldn't miss it if visiting the Hermitage.

Beautiful place to take pictures. You can even rent renaissance outfits and make your own pictures more spectacular or you can just pay one of the many actors in the square dressed according to that period to take pictures with you. We did both ;)

Must visit.. It's right next to the Hermitage so you'll probably visit it. Very impressive.
Ps: bring your own water bottles and snacks as it is very expensive there, amd by very I mean like about 100 Ruble for a small bottle of water.

Grand Square in front of Hermitage.... ... is one of the greatest plazas in the world in scale. It could benefit from the addition of benches or other seating so more time can be spent there from the footsore Hermitage museum goers, but nonetheless transmits the scale and grandeur of a different age, and the tremendous size of the Hermitage and General Staff Buildings can only be appreciated from this vantage point. Watch for Cinderella-like glass pumpkin shaped horse carriages in the plaza, and other lovely but slavery-worn steeds pulling more traditional period calash or coach vehicles. Depressed horses at least have each other's company in these situations, and they show it by nuzzling each other as humans ignore them.
Another Stunning Square. Yet more palatial opulence around a huge square provides more photo opportunities. What it must have been to be a Royal in Russia in its heyday?
Part of the museum . We - me and husband visit this square as part of our visit in the museum. Impressing place mainly because of its size. Very nice.Not recommend wile it is rain

Beautiful place to visit at night.. This is the place which any one should visit during night. Lights all around fascinate any visitor. Many people visit the place during the day, but according to me night visit is a must if you are visiting St. Petersburg.

It is just wow!. Get here early in the morning to enjoy the enormity of the square and to get a full view of the palace without the crowds in all your photos. This is a square unlike most with no tourist cafes and restaurants which I really liked.
Grand old Russian Square ... Must visit place .. Huge square comparable to the Red Square in Moscow .. The openness of the place is a fresh change from the everyday busy lives that we now have.

Beautiful Palace. Beautiful palace for photos & other activities in the square. It's like Red Square in Moscow, Palace Square in St. Petersburg has been the setting of many major events in Russian history.
Breathtaking. One of the most beautiful square of the world, (I live in Rome so I can understand it). It is clean and easy to reach, you can't miss it.

the heart of St Petersburg. Just have a slow walk along the square admiring the Winter Palace facing other magnificent buildings and the Aleksandrovskaya Kolonna dominating the square at the center of it, celebrating military russian victories over Napoleon
You feel the grandeur of it all. It's the view of the Hermitage, it is the history, better stand on it than pass by only, you gotta feel the grandeur of it all.
An historic square. This square is very impressive by its size and symmetry. It gives you the sensation of being in a very historic place. It has served has place for demonstrations and protests.

Palace Square! Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! Must stop and have the camera ready!. We visited the Palace Square on our tour with Red October the last week in July, 2016. This is a place that you must have your camera ready! The Winter Palace is amazing on this view!
This is a must stop when in St. Petersburg!

Stunning and great for a photo or two.. Another tick list place to visit, and it is free to wonder. Wonderful architecture, impressive and stunning. Expansive square. Wander around the buildings and to the river, take a boat on the river. Drinks and food close by. Easy to travel to on the bus (about 20p).
Best square I have seen today . It is what it is. A massive impressive square surrounded by gorgeous buildings. Stand look and ponder the history that has happened here

Great architecture . So this a wow factor of St Petersburg. The square is breath taking and well worth a visit. We did not go in due to large queues. But we stopped to take in all the historic culture. You could probably spend hours wondering around the attractions
Big square. What you see is what you get. Big square with the building of the winter palace and the general staff building.
Watch out for the gypsies. Guys, it's a cool historic location (wish we had a guide with us.. to tell us more..). However, lots of strange people, as in all public places..)

Its a square... beautiful buildings and tourist traps in abundance. Err... a very nice square. A few mins from the river and right in front of the winter palace. Its a nice place to sit on a sunny day. Make sure you walk down the back street on the far opposite side from the Admiralty to see the grantite 'Atlases' holding up the roof of another builing. Apart from that the square is just a place to corral tourists so that locals in costume can charge you for taking a photo.

Breath Taking. We visited Palace Square with a Private tour company Uklotours. We walked into the square via the right side of the Hermitage or Winter Palace at about 10pm. It was twilight and very few people around.. It took my breath away. Standing with the Winter Palace in it beautiful green and white, the massive monument in the centre, then framed by the yellow and white Military Barracks. This building along is a little over 800m long. This is a must see.

Attractive, Fun, and Historic. Dvortsovaya Ploshad if the rough equivalent of Trafalgar Square in London or Tienemen Square in Beijing, but has few peers.The square sits centrally in St. Petersburg and is bounded by the Hermitage museum (and winter palace) and several other beautiful buildings. Architect Carlo Rossi designed both this square and the general staff building that now houses the Hermitage's outstanding impressionist art collection and has a magnificent arch leading out to Nevsky Prospect. A third side contains the beautiful admiralty building. You can see the spire of that building, as well as the more distant dome of St. Isaac's cathedral as you stand in the center. The huge column in the center is notable not only for its commemoration of Tsar Alexander I (who defeated Napoleon), but also because the huge pillar is held up only by gravity. Architecturally, this is one of the most impressive squares in the world.It is also steeped in history. It is, of course, the site of the tsars' winter palace. It was the intended site of the protests that ended in the "Bloody Sunday" of 1905. There is film footage of soldiers marching off to World War I from this very spot. The Bolsheviks took the winter palace from this spot in 1917.And it is still a vibrant hub. The square is full of people throughout most of the day and evening. Concerts are frequent. During our visit one Sunday night there was an elaborate free rock concert put on by the city (with lots of American music).If you are visiting St. Petersburg, you almost can't help traveling through here, but it's really just fun to soak in the energy and atmosphere on a nice day.
Afternoon. A stroll around this very very impressive sqare is a must if you visit St Petersbourg. We liked it alot and my two kids 3 and 6yo did the same.

Impressive. If you are in St Petersburg you cannot miss this impressive square. On one side the Winter Palace (Hermitage) on the other side the Empire style building of the General Staff. In the center the Alexander column. Come early when its almost empty, later on its packed with tourists, but even then worthwhile.
Fun place to walk and watch. Fun to walk in the footsteps of those who have done before us. Great views all the way around the square.

Excellent Square to Visit Day and Night. Very beautiful square with great buildings. On Friday you can participate in different events, to listen to street music or just to dance on the square. You can take 100 amazing photos all around the square and it will never be enough!
Extremely grand. This is one grand palace which leaves you dumbstruck. The history and the architecture inside totally engulfs you.

Beautiful. This Palace Square is very beautiful, very much like Vienna or Paris, very impressive. It has the horse carriages like Vienna. The architecture is very nice and the square is open, spacious and big !
Perfect square. This is a place where beauty and history meet. You can watch the crowd, but souvenirs, go to the Hermitage or just enjoy the architecture.
Spacious square and gorgeous Winter Palace. The square serves the entrance to the Winter Palace and the Hermitage Museum. Some live music performances and people sitting on the square itself.

Main Square in St. Petersburg!. Palace Square is considered to be the main square in St. Petersburg. It is amazing how they made all the different architectural styles come together to make this interesting square. On the north side, you have the picturesque Baroque Winter Palace (built in 1754-62), then across the square, you have the classical yellow-and-white building of the former Imperial Army General Staff (built between 1819 and 1829 by the Italian architect Carlo Rossi). The building encircles the Southern side of the square where you find a central arch through which you can reach Nevsky Prospekt. On the eastern side the building of the former Royal Guards' General Staff tastefully closes the expanse of Palace Square, while on the West the square borders with the Admiralty and the Admiralty Garden. From here, you can see the gilded spire of the Admiralty and the dome of St Isaac's and the view westwards across the stone-clad expanse of Palace Square is quite breathtaking. In the middle of the square the Alexander Column creates an important focal point for this great architectural ensemble. The column in the center commemorates the Russian victory over Napoleon in 1812. Free

All you can imagine. You can visit any time of the day, there is something to look at. The Square is never crowded, but it is so vast. You can do inline-skating, take a walk, buy a souvenir. There are street artists in the evenings so you can listen to the music, have a ride in a chariot or, very often, wait in the queue to the Ermitage museum. There are sometimes soldiers because there is the General Staff building, so it varies and you cant visit only once :)

very special place. is in a fantastic position, near to the river and sea, is a big square with a spectacular palace, i am sorry because the palace was closed, and i can not visit inside next time i want to go in
Historical place where Revolution started. Must see for the historical and sightseeing purpose. Revolution started here in 1917. Ermitage is also here.

Perfect . St. Petersburg is the most beautiful , powerful cities not only in Russian but in all over the world ! It's something different from Europe but amazing ! Place Square is so great, so powerful- you feel like you are not from this time - the power of the beaty Square make you to move into the time it was built ! It is just amazing !
Wow!. Wow, just wow. As the coach came round the corner and this came into sight it was breath taking, absolutely very impressive and worth a visit

Grand City Square and a Cool/Creepy Quadriga. With the beautiful Hermitage on one side and the curved Guards Corps Headquarters embracing the other sides, this monumental square is impressive. The center of the square is punctuated with Alexander Column, one of the tallest columns in the world, and the massive triumphal arch that blows through the Headquarters is cool too. The arch is topped with a quadriga; very dramatic but also looking like something Satin would drive to town in.Being a city-square-nerd I gave this five stars; it is one of my favorites. Maybe they are not your thing, but while you're at the Hermitage it will only take a moment to look.
wonderful square filled with tourists and locals. wonderful massive open square filled with international and local tourists wonderful sight and with much history
Hige and Beuatiful. Amazingly large site for all types of gatherings, what really caught my eye was the beautiful light green painted buildings that surround the square (see pictures)

Huge...watch out for free summer concerts. It's just too wide for my taste, unlike the Moscow Red Square, but it's grand like most squares or grand plaza. We were lucky that there were spectacular summer concerts when we were there this July. Surprisingly, the singers sang mostly American/English songs. But after the concert, a group of young Russian started their own concert in this square and the public sang along. That made us discover the beautiful modern music of Russia.

Don't have to say something else, it's the most famous place in Saint Petersburg . Of course it's the most beautiful and famous place in Saint Petersburg, one of the biggest museums in the world. You can easily find out the information about its collection in the internet so i just want to share some informations that will help you visit the palace easier. If you just go to the palace through the main entrance, it'll take you 2 or 3 hours to wait to buy the ticket as you know everyone wants to visit it. So you have to go to the palace very soon, otherwise you can buy ticket online and i think it's better as you can go inside the museum through an other entrance that you don't have to wait.
Huge palace square with imperial overtones. Expansive square given over to roaming skaters, bards, lovers and just about everybody else sitting around (whenever weather allows).

The glory will make you kneel. Walk around .... Take every color, every view with your breathe & let it go deep down ... I'm a photographer but I turned off my camera in palace square and just watched!!!! ✨Went there at night there were some people singing and dancing ... The great hermitage with its glory will bring you down ... Feels like the colors have influence on everything I could have walked the square hundreds of times

good place to move around.. this is a vast space,with a lot of attractions around it.the best amongst them is the winter palace and the hermitage museum.then there is the office block in front,claimed to be the largest single facade in the world.then there is the big single stone victory pillar at the centre.many tourists and locals alike were moving around, with families and kids.some preparations with stage show and decorations were going on for celebration of school pass out ceremonies.i could not attend the show scheduled to be latter on in that evening.a very good ambience and views.

Impressing large square, that you must consider bearing in mind all the many historical events that happened there.. The square is large, big, impressing. There is a huge column on it and the right top corner and arch where you can come through. The green colour of the Palace is somewhat unusual but nice. The architecture is subtle and romantic. You have to remember the many historical moments, especially during the october Revolution, that happened there.
Awesome Facade. The facade of the palace square is awesome. The stunning architecture of the olden age truly represents its power.

Good Place for photographs. Visited this place during my city tour. Spent 30 minutes guess it was enough. Good place for taking pictures. Took hover board (iwalk) on rent to explore the place. also took 1 hour boat ride which is close to palace square. Overall must visit place.

Seeh as part of our visit to the Hermitage. A lovely square in front of the Winter Palace which houses the Hermitage museum which made a very photogenic stop before early entry with our tour to the museum.

Just go there as soon as you can when u you come to SP. This amazing huge square is something you have to see first. Of course you would have to pass the whole Nevsky prospekt, with all of the shops and crowds, but this square will be a breathtaking things that you will see. I went there for the first evening and stayed arround for a long time because there were some people playing instruments and sitting. Usually it there are quite a lot of people arround.

Smaller version of the Red Square. We came to visit the Hermitage, but the military combined band was here practicing for the Victory Day celebrations, so we go to see the effort that goes into the production. Later, when we saw the celebrations on youTube, it was rewarding to remember the music, the square, the band, and the columns. Great culture.

As big as everything in Russia. The main square is a nice place to take pictures and locate yourself in the city. If it's raining there isn't much places to hide, but the good part is that you can get a picture that isn't full of tourists even though is summer

Magnificent. I felt very excited and grateful be stood in the palace square surrounded by such magnificent, famous and historic buildings. It is a fantastic place to visit and take in the culture and history of St Petersburg. The architecture very impressive and it’s a wonderful place to take photos and sink in the historic atmosphere. If you are visiting St Petersburg I highly recommend visiting this area and if you have time I also recommend taking a tour around the Winter Palace!

Wonderful buildings. The size of the square not only means there is no sense of crowding but also allows you to see these magnificent buildings in all their glory. On the Sunday we visited the square was given over to nordic type skiing on roller blades - amazing!!
Magical!!!. Used SPB tours! HIGHLY recommend them. This place was beautiful. It felt like a step into a Russian Fairy Tale.

Opulence at it's best!. It is amazing to imagine the wealth of Catherine and Peter the Great used to build these unbelievable palaces. Every room you drop your mouth in awe. Incredible artwork and furnishings. Highly recommend a guided tour to learn more of the history. We were there for about 2 hrs but a person could spend much longer.

Winter Palace/Hermitage Complex. Splitting this from the Winter Palace or The Hermitage seems to confuse some people, but this Square is part of the complex and between the Palace/Hermitage buildings and the Staff building that houses the Impressionists works.
WOW. Seems to be a very large compound surrounded by beautiful buildings.All sort of fun activities and photography can be seen happening here.Simply awesome
One can sense weight of history. We walked up and down exploring this square. At the time of our visit there was a display of Red Army hardware dating to the Second World War.
Beautiful. One of the most beautiful places in Saint Petersburg and one of the largest squares in Russia. Entrance to the Hermitage is located here.
Friendly massive square. Atmospheric large open space unexpected in middle of modern large city many small sideshow with very clean surface and God friendly atmosphere
Vast Space - No Rain Cover. The vast square with eye popping buildings bordering it is definitely worth walking around. When it rains though its a long way to run for a cover.
Impressive square in the heart of St. Petersburg!. A must during your staying in St. Petersburg! It is overwhelming to stand in front of the Alexander's obelisc!
Just amazing. This has to be the largest palace square I have ever seen. It is grand and no pictures can really put it into perspective. It truly transforms you to another time period.

Don't miss visiting Palace Square. If your tour group doesn't go here make sure you make the effort to get dropped off here to walk around and enjoy the ambience and absorb the culture and beauty of this place.
Best square in Europe!. Just incredible, If you can ,aproach the square from between the buildings with the Arch over it. Many people enjoying the weather, impromptu performers.
A must see place . Nice place for great pictures. Be prepared to have other people in your pictures, or come super early in the morning, or later in the evening for evening shots
fabulous. wonderful place to visit. huge square, amazing buildings, fantastic photos, breathtaking. we did this just before visiting the Heritage

SPB Tours Rocks! Entry into the Palace Square included!. The Palace was overwhelming in size and art. It was a once in a life time experience. Again, SPB Tours did an AMAZING job including ALL of the preferred sites.

Very large and grand!. This is the huge plaza in the front of the Hermitage and General Staff Museum. Enormous and often used for festivals, displays, concerts, graduations and occasional wedding portrait. A drop off location for tour busses.

Huge Square with Impressive Buildings. Palace Square is just that - a huge square with palaces all around. This square will make for some beautiful photos with the palaces and Hermitage in the background. This is a must see in St. Petersburg.

Absolutely mind blowing. I had seen many pictures of the palace square but nothing prepares you for how grand and opulent it is. The history behind it was fascinating and hearing it from our Russian guide put it in perspective in relation to ordinary Russians. It is definitely a place that must be visited. I would also recommend buying souvenirs from street stands as they are a fraction of the price in the shops or on the cruise ships.

Impressive Square. Great photo opportunities are in this spot on the back side of the Hermitage. Russians walking, biking and enjoying themselves. You really feel like you are in Russia when you stand in the middle of this square.

Nerve centre of St Petersburg with a lot of activity over the weekends.. This is more of an assembly point but is often converted into a venue for all types of events. I have attended music shows to bike performances here. Its also the main entrance into the Hermitage museum and is therefore generally crowded. Lots of cheap food and beer stalls around, not enough toilets though..
Wonderful. Stopped here for a photo shoot from the tour bus, a vast area outside the museum when we were here they were filming1940s. Beautiful architecture.

Another amazing square to visit in St. Petersburg. If you’re visiting the Hermitage museum-complex, your visit would not be complete without a stroll along Palace Square, which offers some break-taking views of the white-and-azure Winter Palace façade, the commanding Alexander Column, and the General Staff Building. The square is of special significance, being the setting for historical events like Bloody Sunday and October Revolution, as well as cultural events like music concerts.

The heart of Imperial St Petersburg.. A wonderful space. It used to be the garden of the Winter Palace, then became a vast parking place for tour buses. Now restored to the public to appreciate the beauty of the Winter Palace facade. The column with the angel commemorates Alexander l and the victory over Napoleon in 1812. Of course most people who come to Palace Square will want to go to the Hermitage but remember that the extraordinary collection of French Impressionist paintings has been relocated to the General Staff Building - the yellow and white building with the arch. Here the collection is sumptuously housed at last, in perfect conditions. Much less crowded than it was on the 3rd floor of the Hermitage; lots of air and space. Downstairs are reconstructed rooms and objets from the Hermitage storerooms. Extremely interesting and a pleasure to visit, if the dense crowds and vociferous guides in the Hermitage are a bit much.

Just an amazing open space. This open area is truly reminiscent of a grand European city and as there are always people milling about, often new brides having photographs taken really sets it apart from what we find in England
Tranquil and stunning. Occasionally filled with the sounds of Russian pop or folk singers, but mercifully free of souvenir stalls and touts.
Impressive. While visiting the Hermitage, the square is a must. Shows the grandeur of St Petersburg and the complex that once housed the royal family along the Neve River.
Breathtaking architecture. Wander this magnificent square, appreciate the architecture and colors, and enjoy the costumed characters (from a distance).
Huge. Arrive early for the Hermitage so you can take pictures from the outside. There a people in historical costume who will pose with you for pictures for a fee.
Giant square . Out of the Hermitage we found ourselves in this huge square all around you find the glorious buildings of the Russian empire it is a must see

The main square of the former Russian Empire. The main square of St. Petersburg. The square surrounded by Winter palace and some other historical buildings. From history lessons in school I remember that "Reds" started the October revolution on this square (in front of the gates on photo) in 1917. And I have strange feelings staying there, because during many years heroic act became a tradegy.

Don't forget to look 360 degrees. Huge square, surrounded by magnificent buildings in each direction. Go in the middle and look all around and don't forget to look up at the statues on the top. Look out for stage coaches offering tours, or Segway's, or bikes - all available to get you around.

beautiful & open square. We found the free walking tour here! Our guide Anastasia was excellent & explained very well about the place!
Must visit on any trip to St. Petersburg
It's a very big square & gets really windy so cover up before you go!
Good Feeling!. It was a nice feeling. When you are standing in the square you can see winter Palace, and Isaac Cathedral. A nice place for taking photos.
Large beautyfull square. Large impressive square with winter palace / ermitage on one side. The monument in the middle. People believe to get long life if you walk 3 times around the monument ☺

On of the most famous squares of St. Petersburg. It is highly recommended to spend some time before entering the Hermitage to look around and imagine the life of that period walking on the Palace square.
opulent palace. Amazed by all the interior decorations from this time period. Rooms were magnificent. Recommend doing on a tour with a guide that can provide the history .

Perhaps the most beautiful squarein St Petersburg.. For me this again is a "must see". Many tours enter the Hermitage via the back doors but the front entrance is on this most beautiful square. Your camera, however good, won't be able to do it justice!
Get there Early and ENJOY. This is one of the Best Restoration Project I have ever seen. the Rooms Decoration and even Furniture are Amazing. The Gardens are the icing in the cake.

Elegant. The palace square, bordered from the north west by the winter palace (Hermitage museum) and from south east by the semicircular government building is one of the most elegant of its kind in the world. it's large and beautiful, with the tall Alexander the first column reigning over it. breathtaking

Very impressive . I love the column of statue of Alexander the 2nd who wore the bettle against Napoleon in 1812. The column is monolith and it's weight 600 tones!!! the Square view is great and definitely one of the bests in Europe!

Beautiful. The 600 ton monument in the middle commerarting the victory over Napoleon is a piece of art standing only on its weight....
The palace housing the hermitage museum, the army HQ are beautiful architecture pieces
Impressive. Really impressive. The buildings are something to see here. Our trip from the cruise port was not so impressive though.
Very large city one could spend 2 weeks and not see it all.. Many sights to see we travelled by cruise ship in June 2016 was in the 80s used Alla Tours excellent company to travel with.
Easy to see. This is an attraction that is very easy to access and you'll see it on your way to the Hermitage. It is phenomenal standing in the middle of it all.

Enermous square. Lived in SPB for a while, but for some reason this square has been remained in my memory. It's just huge and surrounded with beautiful buildings. Definitely check here if you're walking by.

Nice large square, surrounded by lovely buildings. We exited the hermatage museum, and ended up here. its vast to say the least, and they were erecting stages etc for the holiday. The centre piece is the Alexander Column, designed by the French architect Auguste Montferrand. Palace Square has been the site of many parades and festivals over the years, but it has also seen its share of bloodshed. On April 2nd, 1879, Alexander Soloviev unsuccessfully attempted to assassinate Tsar Alexander II here.

Huge space .... We came out onto Palace Square following our visit to the Winter Palace & Hermitage. It's a wonderful space centred with the Alexander Column, it connects Nevsky Prospekt with Palace Bridge, the beautiful bright colours of the buildings are beautiful to see. While we were there they were preparing for the annual Red Sails Festival which celebrates the students leaving education. Music and fireworks.

Beautiful Palace. There are many grand palaces in St Petersburg this is one of the most beautiful. We were lucky very few people were there when we arrived so we stood in the grand rooms almost alone. Fabulous!
Picture perfect setting. recommended to check this out at night as well as the whole facade changes due to the buildings spot lights.
The colours!. I could spend all day staring at the beautiful mint colour of the Hermitage. I had no idea the emperors loved such vibrant and unique colours!
Amazing. Airfull. Inspiring.. It's like the time machine. We stood there with my friends and felt ourselves going to the golden era and back. Breathtaking.

Vast. You won't miss this if you visit the Hermitage. It you don't visit the Hermitage, go here to see how vast it is and at least get a picture of the front of the Hermitage. It separates the main Hermitage/Winter Palace from the General Staff Building.

Magnificent!. The largest square in Europe deserves a visit. I would suggest an early morning if possible as the afternoon becomes quite impacted. There were people in period costumes and there was a beautiful gilded coach, for photo ops.

It takes you back 300 years. When standing in the square and seeing. Closed carriages taking tourists around you literally taken back 300 years. This is a square that is utilised for celebrations and is just absolutely beautiful.

Beautiful building. We are on a cruise tour and got dropped off at the Field of Mars and this was an easy walk in terms of time (but not so great pushing a wheelchair over the cobbles) and the stroll takes you alongside one of the many canals. The square is vast and it is so nice to get up close to architecture this amazing. St petersburg is a lovely city, full of nice people and this stop is an essential for the traveller.

You will not miss that square. If you decided to go to Hermitage, try to be a little bit local and spend some time here. It's a truу heart of the city. Feel the people around, atmosphere and amazing views.
Beautiful, huge square. Lovely atmosphere! There were skateboarders, segways, mobile coffee vans, sovenir kiosks, and lots of tourists. Nice open space.
Great view of the palace. Like other St Pete palaces this one is long and multicolored. Various buildings are included in the complex.

You Just Have To Love the Architecture. This is a great half hour of your time just walking around after walking around the Hermitage for a few hours. Take your selfies or group shots, admiring the variety of architecture and columns. Then head out not far away for dining and shopping. I personally enjoyed my time in the square. It helped that my guide Maria detailed what I was witnessing.

Historical Palace Square of St. Petersburg. This square you must see when visiting St. Petersburg! It has witnessed many historical events. It is also interesting for architect lovers: the barocco style Winter Palace and empire style buildings on the opposite of it from a unique, majestic entity.

Huge Ceremonial Square. This Plaza sits between the Romanov Tsars' Winter Palace (now the Hermitage Museum) and the General Staff Building of the Hermitage Museum. The Plaza is huge and is the site of many of the official governmental ceremonies. The plaza is not quite as large as Red Square in Moscow and is about one-third the size of Tienanmen Square in Bejing. We were in St. Petersburg on the weekend of May 8 and 9, 2016 which is a big celebration in Russia, both in Moscow and St. Petersburg, commemorating Russia's defeat of the German Nazis by raising the Russian Flag over the Reichstag in Berlin at the end of WW II. The Russians celebrate their victories in WWII much more than the U.S. does, presumably because the Nazis invaded Russia and killed thousands of civilians and conducted a siege of St. Petersburg for 911 days and shelled the city every one of those days and essentially leveled it.Most of the notable buildings, palaces and monuments were restorations after WW II. When we were in the square before the parades, we saw the old-fashioned limos parked in the square ready for the parades. We also experienced the huge number of motorcycles in the plaza prior to the parade for the festivities. There is a monument column in the center of the plaza. You need to walk across the plaza to get to the other portions of the Hermitage Museum in the General Staff Building, which is a must-see.

Australian Travellers. A beautiful place to start our walking tour of this city. The square, comprising the winter Palace,Hermitage museum and staff offices is watched over by Alexanders column. The architecture of these buildings is typically Russian and spectacular. Leading from the square is a high arch which leads to Nevsky Prospekt. The only downside to this beautiful square is when it is crowded, pick pockets can be very busy! Best to visit early before the crowds but be sure not to miss visiting.
Unavoidable. You haven't been in SPB if you haven't seen the epicenter. In the middle of Winter Palace, General Staff and Hermitage museums.
A must for picture taking.. You got to stop here to get your proof photo for St Petersburg in front of the Hermitage Museum, which is housed in the former Czars Winter Palace.

Fantastic!. This is truly one of the great squares of the world. The buildings surrounding it are awesomely beautiful and all we could do was to stand and admire the whole scene. It was relatively quiet when we visited but I suspect that it can get crowded at the peak of the tourist season. Nobody should miss this experience when visiting St Petersburg.

A must see. One of the great squares of the world alongside the Red square and Times square. Once you in Saint Petersburg you defenitely go there. Give yourself a slow look around and enjoy the architecture. After that your feet will take you to the tour.

Beautiful Memories. When you come upon the Palace Square you are awe stuck. It is truly one of the most beautiful squares we have seen on our travels all over Europe. It has the beautiful Winter Palace on the south side and the Alexander Column in the middle of the square.There is also a beautiful 28 meter high archway that is a passage to Nevsky Prospekt which celebrates Russia's defeat of Napoleon. This is a place to just savor the beauty of the architecture and take in the atmosphere of the square.

Beware Pick Pocketers Here!. This is a favorite photo site for travelers and also for pick pocket pros, so keep a watch and ladies, keep your purses zipped and guys, put your wallets in your front pockets here... Such people are common at all major sites in Russia, but are worse at others.
Picture Taking. Plenty of elbow room even on a busy day. Taking 360degrees of pictures is worth the time. The street that radiate from PS are good starting points for walking tours of the city.

Inspiring plaza for Russians. This large plaza must be truly inspirational for Russian citizens with flags flying in the breeze. They were actually setting up for an outside rock concert when we were there. Pleasant for the rest of us.

Can't get enough. The square is buzzing of life, but serene at the same time! They had some stages setup while I was there, but nonetheless it was great walking and biking there. It's a very big square and it connects a few very historic buildings in St Petersburg: the Hermitage and the General Staff building.
Beautiful. The buildings are stunningly beaitiful surrounding this huge Square. Police guards everywhere during our visit as Putin was attending the economic summit.

Palace Square - Open Air . Palace square is a vast open space that is located in the southern side of the Winter Palace.
The sheer grandeur of the cobbled square is punctuated by the magnificent edifices of the Winter Palace, Small Hermitage and the Staff building.
A must see. It would be impossible to visit St. Petersburg and not see this square. Interesting and doesn't take a lot of time.

Great Meeting Place and Beautiful View of the Palace. There was an Economics Forum in St. Pete during the time we were there. So the square was fenced in with mountings of giant TVs and bleachers for the upcoming events. Despite that, it was a beautiful place to be. The grandeur of the square cannot be reduced by some mechanical contraptions. The warning I would like to give to visiting tourists is beware of Peter the Great and his wife Catherine. The dressed up characters roam around the square and will offer to take pictures with you, using your camera. Just be advised that they will not let go easily. With a 200 rubles per shot/pose it quickly adds up. You have to be firm when you ask them to stop. There is a chance you could negotiate with them, but we just paid up.
Truly Amazing. Just standing in the square is a great experience. While this is not the Vatican, it reminded me of the Vatican because of the scale of the square and the buildings.
Great surroundings. Surrounded by the Winter Palace/Hermitage and the General Staff Building, this is an imposing square, though the buildings and their contents are, of course, the main attraction.

Not enough words to describe The Hermitage Museum. Before I travelled to Russia I knew that the country would impress me. However, I was not at all prepared to experience so many awesome surprises in one go. St. Petersburg is beyond magic. The city is beautiful, clean, interesting, delicious... Amazing. The Hermitage Museum is by far one of the most beautiful buildings I have ever seen. The collections are breath taking, rich and definitely worth a thousand visits. They say that we need a good couple of years to see everything the Hermitage has to offer... Well, I´m not in a hurry and I can´t wait to go back there again.

Everyone should come there!. Definitely recommend visiting the place! The square is very unique, and has great historical meaning. Everybody, who visits St. Petersburg should take a picture on the square! However, sometimes it can be crowded there.

Beautiful . A visit in St. Petersburg is not complete without walking in Palace Square where you can see the beautiful Hermitage Museum famous for its unlimited colletion of paintings. Watching everyone enjoys the beauty of the place taking pictures or just simply looking around.
Great for pictures. If your visit to St Petersburb is short , you can go to the Palace Square for pictures and take pictures with the people dress as the Zars

Hubub of activity!. The imposing Alexander coloumn stands as a beacon in the Palace Square. Facing the Winter Palace & Hermitage Museum, it forms the center point of a large, open, public space.We came across teenagers skate boarding, artists dressed as Catherine & Peter, the great for souvenir photos, a pair of young men showcasing their musical & singing talent etc..Preparations were on for the gala celebration of St. Petersburg Day on 27 May. Unfortunately, we were booked to fly out that day so missed it :-(Basically, it is a fun area with various activities happening while being surrounded by the most beautiful period architecture.A chill spot!

Overwhelming the senses with beauty, historical significance and greatness in measures !. That is the enormous square that connects the Nevsky Prospekt with Palace Bridge leading to Vasilievsky Island. We found ourselves in this cobblestones square, all surrounding with the breathtaking by their design, elegant features and monumentality, imperial buildings.It is a central city square of St.Petersburg and of the former Russian Empire. So many events through the history of Russia State took the place in this vast square, ending in the beginning of 20th century with the two events of the world significance, that are, the Bloody Sunday (1905) and the October Revolution of 1917. First that captures your sight is for sure the most celebrated building on the square, that is, the baroque white-and-azure ( I've never seen something like that in the world) Winter Palace of Russian tsars, that was built in the period 1754 - 1762. The palace with the decorative columns on the front facade, the high windows, the arched gates through the Palace, the range of the statues of the holy persones and rulers through the history of the world, on the roof of Palace, the central frontone on the top of building with the clock and the flag of Russia.Then across this enchanting edifice, there are the Neoclassical style buildings, which perfectly fit the Winter Palace in their scale, rhythm and monumentality. Here on the opposite side of the Palace, is most impressive the bow-shaped Empire- style Building, in which center is the double triumphal arch crowned with a Roman quadriga, i.e. the chariot with six horses and the soldiers beside of it.In the center of square as a tribute to the Russian victory over Napoleon is situated the colossal Alexander Column, the red granite column with the angel and a cross on the top of it.Nowadays, it is a perfect place for the open-air venue as the concerts and other happenings.Outstanding !!

Stand where history is!. First time I was here was 1993. We were walking here after dark. Suddenly, a lone clarinet started playing Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue. I will never forget that moment. This is a nice place to sit and people watch.
Impressive. Historical location, you feel small in the middle of the square but it allows to take the full dimension of this amazing city.

Far More Welcoming Than Red Square. Although there's not much to see other than the palace and the curved building range opposite, this square holds a variety of activities, like concerts. There are many people milling around and horse-and-carriage rides to be had. It's a relaxed and welcoming place, though there's nowhere to sit, oddly.

Every direction you look there are beautiful buildings.. As we were staying nearby we came here a number of times in various directions. From Nevsky Prospect through the double yellow arch is particularly lovely. A lot seems to happen in the square eg one night was cordoned off for a rock concert. There are lots of toilets here - some in a bus!

Huge square. This is a huge square with the Winter Palace, Hermitage on ne side and the General Staff Building on the other and the Alexander column in the middle. The scale of the buildings is large but really it is not the most beautiful city vista I have seen!

Beautiful Grounds. The palace square and the grounds are beautiful. We went into the palace and had limited time forthe gardens, but the square allows you to have a decent overview if the Palqce and grounds.

Palace Square St Petersburg. Third largest square in the world. Alexander Monument in the center was raised as memorial to Russian armies that defeated Napoleon. Easy walking distance from The Hermitage, St Isaac Cathedral. Scenic location right on the Neva River
AMAZING!. One of the most beautiful places I have ever been! Full of energy and greatness. I really love that place, now it is in my Top5
Great photo op. We stopped by here as we were getting ready for a boat tour on the canals so we only had about 20 minutes. But, it is a great place to see, and a great place for photos.
Wow Factor. The size and scale of the Palace Square and surrounding structures were a sight to behold. Quite nice.
The horse and carriage ride. after visiting the palace for a few hours - its very large , we then took a horse and carriage ride and it was great fun

Great views to Hermitage Museum and Neva River. From Palace Sqr are great views to Hermitage Museum, Neva River and ... long lines that are waiting for entrance to the Museum. :) If you have time, visit this placeat evening, it is more beautiful than in day.
Its a great place to walk around. Despite the fact that I did not get to spend much time in front of the Hermitage, what I saw of it was beautiful.
Better than the pictures. We found the square to be more impressive and bigger in real life than what it looked like on pictures. Really nice to see for the first time.

May 9th Victory Celebration . We were fortunate to be in St Petersburg on their May 9 Victory celebration. Hundred of thousands of Russians filled the streets and the Palace Square waving flags and carrying posters of loved ones lost in WWII against the Nazis.
The Palace square is also the venue for touring concerts like The Rolling Stones.

Huge space. Very regal looking area with large monument, staging going up for free concerts for St Petersburg Day this weekend good photo area
excellent views of the Hermitage

Impressive place. The buildings are a must see. Stand in the middle and take a 360 degree turn to take the full square in. We were in town from the USA on a very special country holiday and the square was full of thousands of people, it was a blast! We were there during the day and evening, I would highly recommend seeing this place.

Wow!. Most impressive square. The only comparisons that come to mind are St. Marco in Venice and St. Peter square in Rome/Vatican. But at the same time very Russian. A must see. Easily combined with a visit to Hermitage

This is one of the tourist highlights. Huge square surrounded by beautiful old buildings - look out for lovely old horse drawn carriages - if you do not have enough money for a ride u can perhaps tips the drivers for lovely pics
Huge square. Huge square surrounded by beautiful buildings. There is an interesting monument in the middle of the square and it is actually standing on its own by its weight -pretty amazing.
Palace Square. The city square surrounded by the pastel palaces needs to be seen. It is a wonderful way to take in the expanse of the Hermitage
Nice for a few photos. close the big river and some small gardens. The square is nice for a stroll and then onwards to the Hermitage
huge plaza, venue for concerts, for skateboarders. This is mainly a place to cross when going to the State Hermitage Museum and other adjacent sites. No cafes to hang out at which are on the plaza.

Gorgeous. Very large square surrounded by beautiful buildings. We got to spend a little time here waiting on our time to go into the Hermitage Museum. You can see all kinds of tourists doing the same thing. No homeless or vagabond locals like you see elsewhere in the great European Squares. If it is a warm, sunny day there will be a number of locals simply soaking up the sun.

Magnificent square. This square is a great place to hang out and watch the world go by. Tourists from everywhere coming to see the Hermitage, locals just having a good time in the sun. So many people on scooters and BMX bikes! So much more active than we mall-dwellers in the Anglo-American world, where town squares seem to have disappeared.
Beautiful. This square is truly beautiful! If you want the true experience of being in St Petersburg go there day or night.....both times of day are absolutely beautiful
Very beautiful. It's a very beautiful square. I found myself speachless when I saw it, the colours are so bright and beautiful...
Big open area . You will definitely come here if you are visiting the hermitage museum. It's a big open area great For photos and selfies.

Walk there on a warm night to know you are really in St.Pete :-). When in St.Peteresburg, this is definitely it. You cannot miss coming to Palace Square. However, if you want to really experience it, I would suggest coming here at night, when the crowds are gone - provided it is warm enough for a pleasant walk. If you can come at daytime and then return at nighttime, all the better. Take a slow walk, look around - everything you see around you is an architecture masterpiece, and all of these together create an impression that will last. From here, either go to Nevsky and treat yourself to something nice in a nearby cafe or bar or go to the embankment and get a great panorama view of the heart of the city.

A big square. There's lots to see around the Palace Square, but the square itself is much like other squares in Europe. It's almost impossible to visit St. Petersburg without going by the square, but once you have seen it, it's not really that different from all other squares. But it's a nice place to take photos with the Winter Palace in the background.
Palace Square. The Palace Square is pretty awesome. There are a lot of cars in the area so be careful. There is also a statute of Peter in the middle of the square that is perfect for picture taking.
Breath taken views from within and out... We spent an entire day here..so wish we could have returned the next day.. So much to see..so cheap in comparison to Europe..

Great!. We walked around the Palace square and were delighted! Very beautiful view of the Hermitage and the bridge. We were lucky with the weather and walked for a long time. Previously, i had no idea that Petersburg is so picturesque city, even better than on the postcards!
Another square. There are so many squares that are wonderful and this is one of them. Rating is average because they are so many squares in St. P that all are worthy of visiting.

Just an open place . Nothing to exciting here but it's right behind the hermitage so drop on here for pictures before or after the museum only if you have time to spare. You can even take a photo from the rear windows in there hermitage
Nice for stoll before or after museum visit. Nice for walking around, taking pictures with the horse carriage or with locals wearing period costumes.
Giant square. Amazing giant wide square with dominant amazing buildings surrounding it. Every visitor of St. Petersburg should visit this place.

Romantic. This large square was impressive, especially on a rainy morning. Situated in front of the Hermitage, it is where official parades and concerts take place. Alexandre the Great's column is awesome!
It's a big place!. Great place to hang out and watch the world go by. Lots of little stalls for pastries and souvenirs.
Beautiful...astonishing!. Huge and humongous square in the city. Plethora of options to eat around near by and do visit rock cafe...great music and amazing place to grab beers.
Hermitage. the winter green palace one of the largest palaces in the world lot of status ,paintings to see inside .cant be described in a message ,you have to go as early as you can.enjoy

Huge and imposing. This is the square where you feel very small in huge spaces. During our visit soldiers were rehearsing for the 9th May parade and it was very interesting to see the old palace and the contrast with the tanks.

In love with ths square. One of the most beautiful and biggest squares I've never been. It's so nice there with the winter palace and incredibly close to everything (the river, the cathedral, the palace, the Hermitage museum...)
It's also the meeting point for a free walking tour.

Must see. In the center of the city, you probably won't miss it even if you don't look for it ;)
There is always a lot of people there.

Impressive View of the palace. We went there early morning and during April, so there weren't many tourists. The square was very open and the kids enjoyed riding Segways there with out any risk of hitting someone.
Must to Watch . Huge complex. Worth visiting the place. Visit to St Petersburg can not be completed if you are not willing to give one full day to see this complex
Grand!. The palace square is grand... Winter palace on one side and impressionists wing on the other side, makes for a lovely sight... Surely can't be missed when visiting hermitage!

A very wet day. It's worth seeing get here early though or book up before it better than being out in the rain like most places while on holiday you what to see as much as possible so once you are in its a day long vist.

Military band performances. I was fortunate enough to visit the square on a Wednesday while a huge military band was rehearsing - very impressive, with an elevated conductor calling the shots! The palace itself is well worth a visit and it is surprisingly close to all of the central St Petersburg attractions. Check the map carefully, most things are within comfortable walking distance.

Impressive. How can anyone visit St Pete and not go to palace Square? It is as grandiose as it looks and houses several importnant buildings and is within walking distance to other buidings. First and foremost is the Winter palace and the hermitage. There is also Alexander's Column and the general staff building on the other side. And it is so close to Nevsky Prospekt. BTW, the square is huge..no wonder theye have had concerts there...Go during the day and go again at night as it will look more majestic with the light on.
Majestic to behold. Stand in the middle of the square and you will be mesmerized by the beauty and size. Locals love to come here and skate and just enjoy the view as well.

Living in the moment of history and photo attractiveness. In many European venues, you have gates, guards, and giggling children that interrupt the photo taking -- but not here. It was so event that the locals wanted everyone to enjoy the freedom of experiencing their country and local tourists attractions. I was lost on my way at one point, but when I looked across the street and saw the Palace Square -- I knew immediately where I was. I rushed over to the Square, bought a delicious hot dog from a locl vendor, found that perfect little Russian Sailor Shirt for a little one, and enjoyed taking photos like a crazed photographer with carte blanche to do photo shoots. The weather was perfect (but it was raining heavily and now the next day -- so I planned the timing to be here to a tee). I am still looking at my photos -- and there one more surprise -- if you turn a 360 degree turn and see the old Square with the Arch (opposite of the Palace), and you will see a momument on top that may make you think of Berlin.
A vast and imposing square. This is an enormous square surrounded by the Winter Palace, the Neva river and the Hermitage with a column and statue of St. Peter in its centre

One of the two most important squares in Russia. Palace Square in St. Petersburg along with Red Square in Moscow are the two most important squares for every Russian. A beautiful mixture of styles from baroque to neo-classicism and empire are imbodied in the adjacent buildings of Winter Palace and General Headquarters. The centre of the square is adorned with Alexander Column. It is easily accessed from Admiralteiskaya metro station. Not to be missed on a visit to St. Petersburg.
Impressive. Surrounded by the imposing buildings of the Hermitage this square is the historic centre of St Petersburg. Expectations were high and it doesn't disappoint at all.

A grand historic square. Entrance to the fabulous Hermitage museum, the square can be a visit on its own at certain times of the day - military music groups, people dressed in 18th/19th century costumes, horse drawn carriages...
great photo area. we loved this open area as it is a great photo spot for the surrounding attractions, well worth a brisk walk around it.
Hermitage. Absolutely not to be missed. Stunning, so much to see. Most enjoyable, informative visit. Great to walk around the outside of the Winter Palace to get a sense of it's size and grandeur.

great. This square, which has witnessed crucial historical events such as the October Revolution, is amazingly wide. Right in the middle of the square stands Alexander Column. The square offers a wide range of entertainment and activities; you can travel on carriages or "gingers" (segway), take pictures with people dressed as Peter and Catherina, or listen to street musicians. The famous Hermitage Museum is located here, so it's also known as "Hermitage Square.

Watch the world go by. Huge square by the Winter Palace worth a visit both day and night (it gets lit up) and good for a stroll before supper. Always something happening here but nowhere to sit and watch it...

grand scale. We strolled down to this square several times during our visit, as it was very close to the hotel. It's huge and has a tall column in the middle, with the Winter Palace/Hermitage on one side and a large archway in the buildings facing it. Impressive and a lovely spot for pictures, especially early in the morning before the crowds arrive!

Stunningly huge . Magnificent square flanked by two of the world's great buildings. If you can score a sunny day great photos to be had. With Tianimann, Esfahan, Red Squ, Trafalgar - one if the world's great public spaces.

Great place to be in the night time. Palace Square looks very different in the darkness. Illumination is fantastic and the whole place becomes like a movie set for historical drama. Definetely recommend to visit after midnight.
Wonderful . A great experience and feeling to be standing in the palace square and knowing that so much of how the last century was shaped happened here.

Perfect for a sunday. If it's a rainy day it's a perfect day to stay the whole day inside because there is just so much to see, between the arts and the building itself, every corner is a reason to stop to contemplate the details and think on how this place used to be 100 years ago, when the Romanov family lived there.
This is where history happens. Standing in the middle of it, you can see how history unfolded - the winter palace, the arch of the general HQ, the Admiralty
