The Winter Palace, General Staff Building with its magnificent Arch and of course the Alexander Column create the ansamble that breathtakes everyone. Square is wide and spacious, but doesnt make you feel small, instead, you get the feeling being a part of something huge and monumental.

Great place. This square is very close to Neva River. The spacious square is mind blowing and great photo stop for tourists. Tourist info counter is located in this square beside mobile toilet facility.

a beaty, specially at night. A great spot.
I would recommend it by sun set, and by night.
Very beatyfull surroundings/buildings...
The whole city is like pieces from Rom or Venice..at least in the city center.
Very acrative for a tourist, and most off it, just walking distance.

Hermitage museum *. Part of the Hermitage museum complex.
Shouldn't be rated as a single sightsee.
I gave 1 just because is part of the complex but is worthy visit it of course.
Very nice. Lovely place to be. It is exactly like the photo. A spacious square with a view of the Hermitage and the winter palace and also in the back is the general staff courters.
Music. Very lucky to have caught the military band practising for the May holiday. A strict conductor went over and over pieces again and again. Very entertaining to watch.

what a square amazing. on the day we arrived at the square the sun was shinning and the square lit up it was amazing to look at it was rather quite as the other tourists were still at st iaacs so we skipped that and went onto the square and when they came over we went over and marbled at the views

Heart of St.Petersburg.. This square is huge and beautiful. Worth visiting if you go to Hermitage museum or anywhere near to it. You can take horse ride or just hang around for a while or just walk past. Buildings around it are old and pretty, also its next to Neva river.

For me is the main square of Russia. The Red Square in Moscow is regarded as the main square of Russia, but it was not always the case. There was a time when the Palace Square was the main area of Russia. And for many who were born and grew up in St. Petersburg the Palace Square will always be considered of paramount importance. The Palace Square is more than twice the size of the Red Square. On one side the Winter Palace and on the other side the General Staff with a magnificent arch is situated, and in the center you will see the Alexander Column, built to commemorate the victory over Napoleon.All together makes an extraordinary magnificent ensemble.

The centre of St Pete. You will find yourself walking through Palace Square on your way to many sights in St Petersburg. We happened to be there Valentine's Day, and at night all the locals were down lighting lanterns and setting them to fly in the sky. It was very pretty to see hundreds of lit lanterns floating away on the breeze.Apart from being a centre for tourist activity, it's also a centre for activity for locals on a weekend. A great photo opportunity.Visited February 2013.

Heart of the city. Impossble to be in the city and not to visit its main square. It is easy to reach on foot from Gostiny Dvor subway station. The Hermitage is right near the square. Beautiful column and arch of the long yellow building that forms square's border.
Great for a stroll. Our hotel was quite close to the square and we enjoyed strolling round to take in the grandeur of the palaces. It is lit up at night and worth a visit then

This is where you'll want to take your selfies. This is the quintessential Petersburg view. If you happen to be here on a weekend, be aware that this general area is haunted by drunk youths still having a good time from Friday or Saturday night. They probably won't hurt you, but they will not hesitate to photobomb you.

Grand is understatement. You may found yourself in a james bond movie entering a huge square with impressive buildings around You. The winter palace, the admirality, the huge obelisque makes you feel small. And makes you remember all the cruel history that took place here. And that is still happening.

Certainly a Grand Square. This very Grand Square is next to St Isacs Cathederal,the column in the centre is the same marble as the Cathederal pillars only it weighs 600 tonnes and is free standing ( not fastened to the ground in any way) just gravity don't miss this and definitely not the Cathederal or any part of St Petersburgh it is a fantastic city

One of the best squares I have been so far. I was lucky to find a very nice weather during my visit to the square so I made lots of photos of the historical buildings you have around this place. It's a nice "taste" before you go to the Hermitage Museum. And yes, be careful with the people that is dressed up, remember that each photo with them will be charged and might be expensive ;)

Vast!. There are so many amazing photo opportunities here! Its beautiful in the daylight but also worth seeing all lit up at night. In the day there are a few souvenir stalls and the odd pastry cart to buy snacks and drinks and at night there are people with horses who you can pay a couple of rubles to for a ride round the square with a unique perspective!

OK attraction outside must-see Heritage state museum. Frankly, this is just a big (OK-huge) open area with monument ringed by the buildings comprising the Heritage state museum and winter palace. The good news is that it can be viewed while entering the real star of the show, which is the buildings themselves with their vast display of artwork. If you wish, you can take a carriage ride from carriages stationed here.

Palace Square. A vast open air square full of history by The Hermitage.Just to walk round it when the visitors have gone is a fantastic feeling.Wonderful photographic opportunities here.I'm still using the pictures I took here as computer wallpaper.The winter months are preferable,but conditions can sometimes be Arctic.Its all part of the Russian experience.Thoroughly recommended.

Amazing!. This is a chef d'oeuvre of the architects in the ex-capital of the Russian Empire, a kind of a famous and incredible Russian space, so wide and impressive... Must go and feel for those who do the first visit to St. Petersburg.

Just a view of the Hermitage. Not a destination in itself!. Much like Palace bridge, I don't understand why people feel the need to separate these. They should just be part of the overall Hermitage experience as frankly, what you really get in the square is a beautiful view of the Winter Palace and not much else (besides sleet in January!) - so yes, you're inevitably going to visit Palace Square while you're in St P but it's not a destination in itself!

January 1905. This is one of the most important historic spots in Russia. It is where Jan. 1905, 1-4,000 peaceful protesters, men women and children were butchered by the Tsar's guards and Cossacks while trying to present a petition to their loving spiritual father, Tsar Nicholas II. Needless to say, many lost faith, and this incident, now known as "Bloody Sunday " is considered to be the beginning active phase of the 1905 Revolution. So don't look at the details, just know where you're standing

Huge!. This square really is massive!! The hermitage is the star of the show at the Palace square, but the other surrounding buildings are also very nice. At Christmas time there is a massive Christmas tree in the square.

Large and beautiful . It's a landmark in St. Petersburg that's difficult to ignore, especially, if you live on Nevskiy Prospect. On a bright sunny day, stroll down Nevskiy Prospect, visiting the Kazan Cathedral, a lot of bridges and picturesque churches. Then you can visit the Palace Square and finally sign off with the Hermitage State Museum.

A great place to ring in the new year with new friends. Had a great time. There was no official countdown to the dawn of the new year, but we did our own a few minutes after the fact with the other friendly folks at Palace Square! There was a spectacular light show projected against the State Building, and it's a really grand place.
Beautiful!. Great square in front of the Hermitage museum. Horses and carriages driving around. In the evening you could watch a projection show on the building opposite the Hermitage. Fantastic!

Vast square with historical importance. This square is overwhelming large--and very beautiful. Try to visit it at different times of the day during your visit since there always is a different feel. Nice views of the column and the Hermitage.

Great Place. The square is huge as is the column in the center of it. The real reason you go here though is to then go on to the Hermitage (Winter Palace) that is connected to the Palace Square. You might be lucky enough to have a platoon of army or navy recruits and get a picture with them.
Big! . A enormous and huge square. Big to walk in and fun to see! A lot of people here and a lot of people in dresses walking around. Guess they work at the museum.
Large and Grand. The square gives you a feeling of grand and historical. Since we visit there during our Christmas time, there is a big Christmas tree on the middle of the square.

Plenty of space in this square. This is close to being the very heart and soul of the city, lacking only the presence of water that is such an indispensible feature of St. Petersburg. There is very little that is Russian about it, not surprising since it was designed by an Italian in the 3rd decade of the 19th Cent. It is immense in both its size and its grandeur. The North side is composed of the baroque splendor of the Winter Palace (Hermitage Museum) that shields it from a view of the River Neva. The South comprises the neoclassical Imperial Army General Staff Building, crescent in shape, and incorporating at its centre a Double Triumphal Arch that leads through to Nevsky Prospekt. The Eastern side is occupied by the Royal Guards General Staff Building that, like the previously-mentioned edifice, is now given over to Government offices. To the West lies the Admiralty Building (now a Naval College) with its attractive gardens alongside. In the centre, a tall monument celebrates Russia’s ultimate victory in the Napoleonic Wars. Ironically, it was designed by a French architect and stands more than 150 ft. tall. Although it is topped by an angel, it is known as the Alexander Column after Tsar Alexander 1 who, as everyone knows, defeated the French Armies single-handedly! Despite its popularity, its sheer immensity ensures that this vast square never seems to be overcrowded.
Very pretty. Palace Square is the main square in St P and where the famous Hermitage / Winter Palace is based. It's incredible and if you've studied any Russian history, it's a must.

A Grand Space With Grand People Watching. A balmy Saturday afternoon in the autumn provided us with a wonderful occasion to mingle with the crowds and see all shades of locals enjoying the weather, the space, the vendors, music, flash mobs [2 separate], the vistas and each other. It is probably also elegant -- if cold -- in winter, alone. But when it's hot, it's HOT!

The Palace Square. This is a vast square, surrounded in part by the Hermitage Museum, the (Winter Palace - which is now part of the Hermitage Museum), General Staff Building and the Guards Corp Building. There is a huge column of red granite in the center of the square, designed for Alexander I for his victory in the Napoleonic war. The colors of the buildings and their unique Baroque and Empire styles enhance the architectural splendor of the entire Palace Square. When I was there the first day, there was a motorcycle rally and a few thousand bikes were parked on the square; being a motorcyclist, it was an interesting sight, especially with the unique old architecture and the tall Alexander Column!Jon Lefeber

Good meeting point with strolling costumed actors. News - the Hermitage has just purchased the last yellow curved buildings facing the south side of the square, so hopefully they will fill them with currently-stored collections in the future. Driving on and around the square is allowed, and there is still a small, free parking lot on the east side of the side where taxis may be easily found (although not at all easily stopped on the fast boulevard along the west side of the square). Newest and deepest Admiralskaya metro stop is two blocks south of the SW corner - definitely walkable from the metro, even in cold weather.

Spend all day at Palace Square. At the end of Nevsky prospect street are the Palace Square.Located on Neva river.Wide and surrounding with famous building in St.Peterburg.The Green building-The State Hermitage Museum(Winter Palace),Long yellow and white with big gate - General staff building,Alexander column in the middle of the square. Across Nevsky prospect you will see Golden dome of St.Isaac,s Cathedral, and Yellow building-Admiralty .You can take Hydrofoil (Peterhof Express) to Peterhof near by Palace square.

Impressive Prospect View. It's just a MUST to see like almost everything in St.Petersburg.when you are right on the Palace square there is prospect wherever you look. and prospect view has been always impressive for me.also good to take photos.Mind the crown on the top of the Hermitage, which is almost burning under the sun.

Panoramic. Standing in the place where the October Revolution occurred in 1917 is incomparable. The view of the Winter Palace, the Central Staff Building, a park to the left and the sound of Nevsky Prospect traffic crossing over the Neva is unparalleled.
Beautiful. It is very big and surrounded by Hermitage and other beautiful buildings. if you visit it at sunset of a delicious sunny September day, like me, you will love it.
Palace Square (Dvortsovaya Ploshchad). right outside the hermitage. to me there wasn't much striking about it to me. it's really big though, so you know... russia and stuff

Must see - Impressive. Breathtaking area near winter palace, huge square surrounded by superior architecture on all sides. Admiralty, St. Isaac Church and Alexander Column can all be see at same time in a wonderful photo opportunity

Massive square - great!. What a great big space. All the buildings / Palace around it - you have to visit here. Lots of things to see, horses and carts, just around the corner you can get your photo taken with monkeys or parrots if you like that sort of thing. People watching is fun. Snacks. Each of the buildings are a site to see. Such history. Definitely visit here and take a walk around the area.

Breathtaking. Simply massive square with the Winter Palace on one side and The Alexander Column in the heart of it. Magnificent surroundings - camera a must - and worth viewing both in daylight and at night when it is all lit up. This place is a unique part of world history - do not miss if in St Petersburg.

Massive!. The Palace Square has a great location, entrance to the Kremlin is off it. Its also so large its hard to miss! Its good for people watching. There are carriage rides available, and segways for hire. The buildings that surround it are beautiful, and you will be blown away by the size. The Alexander Column is a focal point and right in the centre of the square, and itself is large (on par with the square).

Beautiful Square. Great place to go or even just walk through. You can get some great shots both during the day and at night. Horse drawn carriage in the square, a tourist information station (info box) and some places to buy some gifts. Make sure to stop and just admire the sights if you're walking through it to the hermitage museum or anything else around it
Place Square St Petersburg. Cant believe i have actually stood in this spot. felt very safe. absolutely beautiful. you must get out and feel this place not just drive past.
Busy Square. This square is busy, there were horse drawn carriages to hire. It is lit up at night and you can get some great shots there.

meet you at the Column in Palace Square. great place to meet up - really hard to miss. Near the Hermitage and Winter Place, the Neva river boat tour departures, the city bus tours, tourism office and carriage tours.

An enormous square in the heart of St. Petersburg. We exited the Hermitage Museum/Winter Palace and walked right into the Palace Square. One is easily awed by the sheer size of this main square of St.Petersburg franked by Palaces and the Army General Staff. The most eye catching of course is the Alexander Column right in the middle of the Square. This red granite column is said to be 47+ meters high and weighs almost 600 tons. Wonder how they lift this upright in the 1800+ The other attraction is of course the Double Triumphal Arch crowned with a victory chariot. These two monuments were said to be built to celebrate the victory over Napolean in the war of 1812. Nowadays, the Square has been used for open air events including concerts and we were told that celebrities like Andrea Bocelli, Elton John, Madonna and the Rolling Stones had put up shows right here.
Unique & Impressive. Hugely impressive granite monolith in a vast square surrounded by the magnificent facades of the Hermitage / Winter palace and the buildings of the Imperial General Staff

Huge. The palace square is very big and you will find yourself very small when you are there. This square is very impressive and is surrounded by huge buildings with Hermitage museum on one side. It's so huge that it is very difficult to catch its whole view in one picture.

A Brand New Museum Facing the Hermitage on This Square: the Distribution of Modernist Painting in St. Petersburg. If you wish to see the Hermitage's great Henri Matisse murals and paintings that once belonged to famous early Moscow private collectors, you need to know that these have now been transferred immediately across the square to the new 21st Century Museum recently created in part of the vast block known as the General Staff Building. (For the time being, Picasso and other early modernist European works remain less impressively displayed within the Hermitage.) The stunning Matisse works are located on the top floor if the General Staff Building and serve presently as a kick-off for a more contemporary display of installation-type art, which is innovative and good of its kind. Most Russian modernist works are now part of the collection of the so-called Russian Museum nearer Nevsky Prospect, a revelation in their own right when seen together in their present well-lit recent display there.The Twenty-First Century Museum in the General Staff Building is completely uncrowded. It requires a separate entry ticket from that of the Hermitage across the square.

Vast and massive monumental square. Very large and open area where tons of tourists and locals met and gather to enjoy all the breath taking viewers of the near by palaces. We were lucky to visit on Flag Day when they set up a large grand stand and brought in military vehicle for children to admire and play on as well as commemorate all of Russia's military service men and women. Great location for concerts and public gatherings, a must see!

Impressive place to see. The Palace Square is a very impressing square with huge free standing granite column in the middle. You feel very small in this place. The buildings surrounding the square are huge and extensive and look even different iat different hours due to the light. Very impressing and breathtaking. Very nice spot to be
Beautiful at night.. This is a beautiful place in the daytime, but even better at night, when all the buildings are nicely illuminated and there are fewer people around.
the Hermitage square. Its the square in front of the Hermitage, why wouldn't you want to walk around and experience this happening place?

Spend there at night time during the summer. This place is close to one of the mechanical bridge that exist on Neva river.I spend a lovely night evening that started by looking on the opening of the bridge while there was a street artist that play russian rock all the time, and then I went to the Palace Square where I found more street artist and young people having fun, there was some very magic and young atmosphere. I'll suggest spend an evening like that at some clear and worm night during White nights or even any other summer night.

A BIG place !. Standing at this square you really feel small !! With the biggest single piece granite column in the middle of the square, and with the Palace and the other surrounding buildings - this is really breathtaking !
Spectacular. This is one of the most impressive squares I have seem in any city. It is extensive with so many amazing building around the square. It is breathtaking
packed. It's stunning and impressive but crowdy. You will see a lot of Russian people do activities here even small concerts or sports.

Very imressive. One of greatest architectural attractions in Europe. It is strongly recommended to visit the square more then once, at different hours (morning - day - evening - night): each has its one impression.
magnificent grandeur as far as the eye can see. Spectacular city centre must see! Artisans, pedal bikes, a monkey or two and a beautiful square as far as the eye can see!

Makes no sense to have this as a separate listing. If you go to see the Hermitage (which you will), you'll see the Palace Square. As a standalone landmark, it ranks as 1 out of 5 if we're being generous as its only merit is the view of the Winter Palace + the arch of the HQ. You will spend 3 minutes here at most, taking photos of yourself in front of the Winter Palace - that's all there is to say about it.

Must visit Palace Square. Place Square is a busy part of St. Petersburg's central district. There are many tourists and natives alike relaxing on the square, roller blading or admiring the Winter Palace/Hermatage Museum, listening to concerts etc. The palace is beautiful day and night. I trip to St. Petersburg is not complete without a visit to this historic site.

Huge Square in the Heart of the City. You can't miss Palace Square if you're visiting the Winter Palace (Hermitage Museum). It's very large and historic. This is the scene where the 1905 Bloody Sunday events and the 1917 October Revolution took place. The Alexander Column in the middle of the square was erected to honor Tsar Alexander I, the victor of Napoleon.
Huge Space. This felt like I was in the heart of Russia. Absolutely amazing space surrounded by beautiful buildings. Loved it.

Large and clean. It is a beautifully planned square, offsetting the palace. It is huge and impresses you not only for its size but also for its cleanliness. There is not a single piece of litter anywhere you can see.

A great square!. The square is very big, surrounded by beautiful palaces and other buildings, including the Hermitage (the Winter palace). It has witnessed a lot of historical events and you can feel it while you stend there. This is really the heart of the city.

Extensive. This square is surrounded by a multitude of magnificent buildings also with views of spires and domes further afield. While we were in St Petersburg, the square was being used for a military celebration and was full of people, military personnel, military hardware, a huge stage plus supporting crew. There was also a temporary tiered seating stand, that we used one evening on our way home, to watch rehearsals.

Huge area, liked it!. The square is absolutely massive!! Very impressive with the beautiful buildings all around. Nice area to take some time and just look around. We took lots of great photos here. I enjoyed it!

Nice place to make a foto!. Yes, it is really nice place to make a foto to show that you have been in St.Peterburg. If you want to be in epoche of Peter - there are a lot of "Peters" and his ladies in the costumes of that epoche.
Big open space.. Handy landmark for getting about. Lots of people will ask you take pictures of them. Public toilets at one end.
Must be visited. One of the largest and beautiful squares in Russia. The main entrance to Hermitage is also can be found here.

Soaking In The History......Remarkable!!. Just sitting in the square soaking in the history of all that has happened here and all the beautiful buildings surrounding it. It's difficult to get your head around it all, but it's fun trying! Would love to go back and make more time to enjoy all this place has to offer!

Colossal!. That was the biggest square i have ever been to! Colossal! Makes you feel how small you are! it was a beautiful square with beatiful architecture surrounding the vast area. I think many tourists are missing another aspect of the square. During summer time it turns into a lovely place late at night. We went there at 3.30am (at the dawn) in the morning on Saturday. There was a local street performer singing lovely and young people (mostly local) were dancing around him. Great experience! Strongly recommended..
Evening visit. If its possible for you go there at evening in weekend, Nice atmosphere, both locals and tourists are there.

Photo Op place. This is where people get their pictures taken. Many only want to get to the Hermitage and just breeze through or stand in the long lines winding into the square waiting for entrance to the Hermitage. I liked it so much better years ago when I could enter the Hermitage from the Neva side...... Maybe learn a little bit about the Alexander Column, 1905, the big complex with the arch you walked through from Nevsky.....

At the very center of things...!. Everywhere you look there is history and magnificence! Winter Palace, Alexander Column, General Staff Building etc. Nevsky Prospekt and Admiralty Square are also minutes away...
The Plaza. Simply reathtaking. The history behind makes it an unforgetable place to viist. The Hermitage and arch surrounding it, impressive.

Best Time at that Square is evening. you will keep crossing this square during your stay as it is flanked by hermitage, summer palace and enroute to Neva River and other attractions. i loved this square in the evenings... there were musicians playing, tourists lounging on the square, the weather was lovely..

A great starting point before the Winter Palace. This site is right outside the Winter Palace/Hermitage museum. Such an expansive square in the middle of such a crowded city. Worth some photos before going into the Hermitage.
Iconic. This square is very iconic of St. Petersburg and I found that it is one of the best places to take photos of the Winter Palace.

Huge!. This square is huge. Here you have the most imortant buildings nearby. Tourist flock here all year to get pictures of the winter palace and selfies with that building. Open area with no traffic so that people can sit down, relax, enjoy the surroundings.
Super pretty. A lovely looking square where you can view the Winter Palace. Not spectacular, but nevertheless beautiful.
Eye catching. Being able to stand in Palace square is amazing. The panoramic view is breathtaking. The Hermitage, palaces, St Isaac's and the Admiality all within view. It is really quite impressive
beautiful square. we went out to the square after visiting the Hermitage its jaw dropping beautiful you would need panoramic photos to show the whole square.worth a visit.

A Square where everything seems to happen. Most people walk through this Square dominated by the Alexander Column (a favourite meeting place) on their way to The Hermitage entrance. If meeting people here beware as the Square gets closed off periodically for events. I saw a Police Graduation Ceremony, a Street sports event (BMX stunts), and a type of skiing event - see photos. There are public toilets just off the Square housed in a single decker bus!The vista looking around the Square is impressive - all those fine buildings which include the General Staff Building and the Winter Palace. Standing in the Square you can picture in the mind's eye important historical events such as the October Revolution of 1917 which have shaped modern Russia
Beautiful Palace. It was under construction when we went but it was beautiful big and amazing , just standing on it watching all around

The Center of Everything. Nevsky Prospect may be the modern center, but this is the traditional center of Russia. It is awe inspiring to stand in the middle of this square. Whereas Red Square in Moscow has a creepy beauty, this place has a elegant beauty rarely seen today.

Beautiful. The palace square is the central point of the city. The monolithic monument in the center is absolutely fantastic, with an interesting historical and engineering story.While visiting the city you'll stop there for sure. Take a few minutes to admire this widespread place.
the most impressive. The monumental Dvortsovaya ploshchad is one of the most impressive and historic spaces in the city. Stand well back to admire the palace and the central.
Only a wide open space. If you walk from the Admiralty Arch to the Winter Palace, you will have to walk across it. Apart from that, it is not really worth time to visit.
angel of the city. the square where the angel is...the place where the great state hermitage museum and the winterpalace is. a place you must see...

Beautiful architectural structure. Palace Square is one of the most beautiful places in Europe. It is very balanced with the nature in St. Petersburg. One of the "must see" and "must photograph" squares in the world and I like that they keep it practically "commercial free", in July 2013 we were lucky to listen to a free unforgettable concert; however, last time we visited on June 29, 2014 and we have seen there many attractions like skateboard platforms, basketball goals and other playgrounds. I do not think it is a wright place, does not match the square and does not increase the value.

This is a must see moment. For those interested in the tumultuous history of St Petersburg, a visit to the square and moments of reflection are in order. After all, it all began here in 1917, and the Seige of Leningrad is best contemplated from this location just outside the winter palace and the Hermitage. St Petersburg is a truly beautiful city, and this square is on par with St Peters in Rome. Truly breathtaking.

Great photographic opportunities. After visiting The Hermitage take time to wander around this square. Take photographs and soak up the atmosphere. You can even take a ride in a horse drawn carriage or have your photograph taken with a costumed lady or gentleman.
Huge. The square is huge. Some big concerts or events are hosted there. Good place for panoramic pictures of Winter Palace.
Excellent. Visited today @ 28/06/2014 , many cool activities going on this day. Enjoyed the moment with a big smile . =)
just stunning. unforgettable moments and feeling, goosebumps, and memories...we were there during citie"s birthday and there was a concert...almost unreal during white nights..

Nice place . It is a very nice place with nice building around and you need to visit the winter palace there , there is a nice chance to see a performance for some music groups there and if there is a celebration it is also near to one of the open bridges that open at 1:30 am
Big beautiful square. It has many people, nice view to hermitage, central monument and "main shtab". There is entrance to hermitage museum from Palace square

Pretty Cool Square. This is a cool square adjacent to the hermitage/winter palace. I wouldn't plan on coming here unless I were going to the hermitage. It is just another "town square" with some cool photo ops. If you, have such little time that you aren't visiting the WP it is probably a waste of your time to come go see a cathedral.
Love it...!!!. Very amazing Palace Square with full tourist, good attraction for shootings, quiet place, have a hourse dokker and tuk tuk.
Imposing, huge, great for photography. A vast area with a central granite self supporting pillar that dominates the area. Imposing buildings on opposite sides that make you snap away at length.
Vast impressive square,. Great to walk across this square en route to The Hermitage. The space and grandeur will impress even the most jaded palate.

Great - if nothing is happening. An immense square made by the buildings that surround it. however, if there is an event on there maybe scaffold all over the place that obscures the views. Nice in daylight but great looking at the well lit buildings at night.
Very large square.. Lovely square in the sunshine.The Hermitage is in this location.Worth a visit.There are also carriages if you fancy a horse and trap ride around.
Great Open Space. Great open space at the heart of the city. The square is a great place to people watch, but it can be a heat trap in the summer.
Great Architecture. Surroundings are a of a great site and if well explain and narrated by guide, you can imagine how it was before. Strolling around is very relaxing.

Impressive. Grand square that tells of the grandeur gone by of the city.
Made all the more so by the military parade we witnessed as they practised to celebrate VE day,rocket launchers, tanks and all.

Beautiful surroundings. This square has the most beautiful buildings surrounding it, there are beautiful horse a carriages you can go for a ride in, as well as skaters and people selling all kinds of stuff. The winter palace is one of the surrounding buildings. Lots happening here

Magnificent City Square. A wonderful City Square which is one of the highlights of St. Petersburg. The Square is really grand and surrounded by beautiful buildings and a column. The architecture of the buildings is splendid, one of which is the Winter Palace which is part of the Hermitage. The Square has a lot of life going on and is a good place for people-watching. This magnificent city square is quite capable of holding its own with any of the other great European squares.

Empty. Three things worthwhile. Hermitage facade, longets facadew in something or other and the tallest needle with no foundation. The statue atop seems to be giving the world the finger. Pretyy appropriate.

Big beautiful square. The square is in a central position is St Petersburg being next to the Hermitage museum and Winter Palace. The square is huge and can take you while to stroll around the area. There is a tourist info office to the side of the square.

This is a happening place. situated between the Hermitage and the buildings originally occupied by the Military this always has things happening from horse and carriage, markets, Young people roller skating or riding motobikes ...rarely a dull moment and a great place to photograph the Hermitage

Beautiful. The square is a good place to start exploring St Petersburg. It is worth taking time to really look round the square as there is a huge amount of detail to take in - I missed the gold balconies on the General Staff Building at first glance. Exploring the periphery of the square is worthwhile - don't miss touching the big toe of the left foot of one of the statues supporting the New Hermitage Portico for good luck.The square is exposed so even on a good day a cold breeze may whistle through, so be prepared with layers!
one of the most beautiful square of europe. very nice place, from tehre you can visit everythingvery nice every moment of the day and the night

Lovely views. Ouside the Hermitage and Winter Palace this gives a lovely view of the Hermitage. It is a wide open space with a monumnet and good views of the buildings. The Hermitage entrance is off here.
Greate place where usually go free concerts. Many rollers, bikes, even horses and "veloriksha" at summer. On visible place stands trailer with toilet and it looks funny.

Impressive. Very large square with the ornate buildings surrounding it. Military bands practicing their marching when we were there. Don't get sucked into having your photo taken with the dressed up people.
When is a square a circle? When it is a Ploshad!. The square had pony & trap rides available but was generally used as a crossing point for walkers to their various destinations.

"Majestic Palace Square". The heart of St. Petersburg is Palace Square. This massive public space is located between the main facade of the Hermitage (Winter Palace) and the Palace Administrative Building that once housed the civil service for Imperial Russia. It is a grand space and at its core is the tall, cylindrical Alexander Column. Tsar Alexander II commissioned this massive monument to commemorate the victory in 1812 over Napoleon, the same great battle immortalized in Tschaikovsky's "1812 Overture." The panoramic view of the Hermitage, the Admiralty and the Palace Administrative Building as seen from Palace Square is one of the most majestic in St. Petersburg
Great pre soviet architechture.. The buildings are well restored are surprisingly colourful. You get a good sense of what life was like during the Tsarist era.

The most spectacular square in.... ...the world? In my humble opinion this beautifully designed plaza is not only impressive because of its grandeur but also because of its elegant clean architectural lines. It easily rivals St. Peter's Square in Rome and possibly Place De La Concorde in Paris - go early in the morning (or if you happen to go in the off-season) and you will be awestruck by the square's magnificence. To me this square is what St. Petersburg is all about - historically and artistically.

Grand Square. The Palace Square is a major attraction in St Petersburg. The square is in front of the Hermitage and surrounded by historical and magnificient buildings. There is a prominent column in the centre known as the Alexander Column. The square is a lively place swarming with tourists. One can take a buggy ride too from here. This is a must visit if you are in St Petersburg

Careful of the Ice in Winter. It's just a massive square, but the buildings surrounding it make it a brilliant spot to take photos of the city, plus it's also close to the river, so really, it's excellent for a photo op or to see many soldiers in uniform if that's your thing...I'm guessing that in the summer months, it would be packed with street stalls and thousands of tourists, but in winter, it's very slippery due to the ice/snow build up. It's really empty during the winter months though.
Big square!!. It is just a big square next to the Hermitage Museum,nice for a walk and for taking some pictures in the city

Big, Impressive and Well Maintained!. Visited St Petersburg in September 2013 to find the weather moderate but slightly cool. En route to a guided tour of the Hermitage Museum was struck by the absolute beauty of Palace Square.To say the least it is simply a magnificent plaza that enjoys not just a breathtaking occupation of space but the beauty of the buildings surrounding the plaza itself are gorgeous.I enjoyed reading up on the history of this part of St Petersburg when I returned to the USA. In my opinion it's a definite must-see just to enjoy the overwhelming use of space and, of course, to enjoy the historical architecture that surrounds you!I recommend having a comfortable pair of walking shoes and to take approximately an hour to 75 minutes to walk around and embrace the beauty of this part of SPB.

A magnificent, historical urban space. Palace Square is a magnificwent space bounded on one side by the winter palace and on two others with large formal government office buildings and open to the street on the fourth. It gives a sense of the power of the czars and the anger and resentment it generated leading to the aborted revolution of 1905 and that of 1917 which lead to the overthrow of the imperial government. This square was the epicenter of both. Thousands fought and many died on this square. When you are in the Hermitage in some great gilt hall and looking down onto the square from a lofty height and behind 5 foot thick walls you can get a sense as to how easy it would be for a czar to be arrogant and feel impregnible.

Grandeur Defined!. When you set foot at the square, you will know why it is something that only a visit in St. Petersburg can give you. And does it deliver!The whole place is a 360 degree assault to the sentences! Everywhere you look is a Tourist Spot, from a Square's center to the magnificent edifices built around the area, you know you have arrived!It is so big you will need 1 hour to go around just looking at the outside of the buildings and looking at architecture at its best.If you want to go inside in the museums, you will need more time. I would have to say, this is better than the Red Square. Albeit the Kremlin is no other, the Palace Square brings something out of you that you can only imagine if you were part of Madame Bovary Fantasy.Huge and Beautiful, it will be an assault to your senses!
Big Square. The Square is very big and it pays to have good walking shoes. Was surprised that there were so few merchants in the square on a Sunday selling items

Must-see in St. Petersburg. Palace Square (Dvortsovaya ploschad) is something that you must see when you visit St. Petersburg. The square is really big, and during the summer time different concerts and other events are held in it. However, it might get very crowded during summer; there are also some weird things in the square like WC's that are actually located inside the buses/It's better to come here in the morning, especially during summer, when there are still not many tourists and when you can get the best pictures.

Grandeur plus. We approached this from the Hermitage side and were absolutely blown away by the hugeness and magnificence of this square! It is vehicle free and even with lots of people in it it looked virtually empty. The size of it is to be seen to be believed!

Go, if only to marvel at the winter palace. This is a vast square with not a lot going on other than the statue of Alexander I which is a pretty impressive column in the middle, get your wide-lens on for that.The outsides of the square houses some grandeur buildings, the winter palace; guard corps headquarters and the general staff building.Definitely worth a visit, even if you're not going inside the hermitage.

One of the two. If you are in Russia, you MUST visit two squares: Red Square in Moscow and Palace Square in St. Petersburg. One interesting fact for those who don't know: if you travel by car from Red Square Moscow through Tverskaya St (улица Тверская) and Leningradsky Avenue (Ленинградский проспект) and keep going straight, your final destination will be the Palace Square. It will take you a day of driving though. The square is in front of the Winter Palace, or Hermitage museum. You can visit this famous museum and then take a speed boat to Peterhof to enjoy the Summer palace and its fountains. But don't try to do it all in one day - too much. Spend a day on Palace Square and Hermitage and another day in Peterhof. Enjoy!

Great square . Great square in the heart of the city's tourist attractions... Russian museum hermitage etc.Well worth spending some time here admiring the architecture. And chilling out between museums!

Beautiful Square. This square is in front of the Hermitage museum and the General Administrative Staff buildings. Quite impressive. Large in size. The Alexander column in the centre looks elegant. There are couples dressed up like the old royalty and you can get yourself photographed with them for a price.

It's not square visiting a real SQUARE.. Overview of the state Museum, the Hermitage, the statues, and other historical buildings. We were there on Sunday, when it was very windy, and saw a temporary roofing structure blow off down into the street below, quite scary.
Reminds me of Milan. A beautiful square that reminds one of being in a central European city. Absolutely gorgeous - worth a visit. Also close to shopping on Nevsky. :)

Great place to stop by before Winter Palace. Located between two very impressive, large buildings (the Winter Palace and the Administrative building) this vast square is a great stop to visit before going to the Winter Palace. It is quite vast & the view of the historic buildings will blow your mind off. It's also full of local young people like bikers, skateboarders etc. and some people just sit on the ground drinking their kvas and chatting.Can be nice for a little rest before visiting Hermitage, and certainly great for taking photos.

Magnificent - Palace Square. This is accessed when you come out of the rear door from the Winter Palace and is between it and the General Administrative Staff building. Imposing in the middle of the Square is the Alexander column with the obelisk on top. The history dating back 200 years is amazing and there have been many series of the parades held over the years. Good place for photo opportunities, just a pity there is a lot of scaffolding which should now have been taken down.Also the venue of many good concerts such as Placido Domingo, Paul McCartney, Rolling Stones and Elton John.
comfort tour st petersburg. to look at all these magnificent buildings around a square was a sight to behold the structure of the arches was some engineering

A celebration of Napoleonic victory. Grand open space bordered by the Winter Palace on one side, and the General Staff and Ministries buildings (linked by a Triumphal Arch) on the other, with the impressive Alexander Column in the centre. Nicely, it is still used as a public space, hosting the end of a fun run and children's races on our visit.
Impressive. The square is huge and is surrounded by nice architecture. Buildings are nicely restored and there's always something going on. Well worth a stroll around.
An impressive square. The square is just outside the Hermitage and it has the Alexander Column. Worth taking a stroll in the evening, the grandeaur just stands out.

Impressive square thats round. The square is big and is located in front of the hermitage with a tall column at its centre. Its just a square but is impressive due to its size and the buildings that surround it. It is pedestrianised, and there is a tourist information at its edge which was useful. The only thing that annoyed me slightly was that when I was trying to take a photograph of the hermitage, these people dressed in period costume were hassling me to take their photograph and then charge me for the priviledge. Thats the only reason I didn't give it an excellent rating.

wonderful feeling of space and grandeur. This place is huge but apparently not by Russian standards. All around are wonderfully-restored buildings. If you're like there maybe a military exercise in it

important place to see. Historical place , historical center. Famous for its architecture and revolution events in 19th and 20th century. Compare it with visit to Ermitage art museum. Be carefull about pickpockets
Famous square. Famous square with Alexander Column. Buildings around it are nice, however square itself is kinda boring: it's just huge area with nothing on it.

Wide open square!. Very nice and historical square, surrounded by top attractions. You will definitely go there if you go to St Pete. In the center, Alexander Column is the meeting point for the free-tour (book online).

Huge. Massive - always something going on there and surrounded by stunning buildings. With the Hermitage behind you and the triumphant arch in front this square is a great point of reference for people wandering around the city.
Big square. You cant miss it when touring St. Petersburg :) Nice place for photos. Lots of happenings take place on this place, so the amount of people may vary a lot.
Perfect. Beautiful square under the arch. Perfect architecture design. It remind us of St-Peter square in Rome. You won't miss it if you visit the Hermitage.
Lovely big area. Beautiful buildings and had a go on the Segways round the square - great fun! A musician was playing and it was a lovely atmosphere.

spacious, good chilling out place. love to just people watch, look at the attractions in this square, sit on its floor while sipping coffee and eating pastries. i think no single tourist miss this square at all.
Large expanse. Bordered on one side by The Hermitage this is a massive central space. Not a lot to see, but well worth a visit as you transit to The Hermitage or others parts of the city.
A great view of the Hermitage. Tis wide plaza is great for getting pictures of most of the buildings that comprise the Hermitage museum.

If you are going to Saint-P, you gonna be there anyway;). The heart of a city, as simple as that) great viewes, colorfull buildings, the Angel in the middle, just a great place to walk thru. Also (if you need it) there is a tourist info center and toilets ( in a blue ,nowhere-going bus, lol). The square itself is between the Hermitage and old Military Headquarters , and it is big, pretty big, it is realy hard to miss, even if you try to do this)And there is a bunch of shops with expensive souvineers "from Russia".

Ordinary historical square. Nothing much to do here other than to savour the historical significance of this place, and overpriced ice cream.This is the site of Bloody Sunday in 1905 as well as the 1917 Great October Socialist Revolution - to those who are interested in history like myself, please do read up about these significant events before visiting to appreciate it fully. This is where the Bolsheviks forcefully took over the government and the rest, they say, is history.To the rest: You can hang around here if you arrived too early to the Hermitage, or after your visit. There's nothing here but photo taking opportunities of the exterior of the State Hermitage as well as the Alexander Column - while waiting for the Hermitage to open of course, before the hordes rush in.
Broad vistas. A little tip for a photo opportunity: take a photo from the Matisse room on the 2nd floor of the Hermitage for a wide panorama

HUGE. It was a thrill to see the large square that we'd seen in so many movies in person. It's easy to imagine the thousands upon thousands of people that can fit into the square whether it be to demonstrate or to celebrate something. When we were there only a few people were walking around and we had a clear view of the outside of the palace which is a site in itself. However limited your time the square is worth a quick stop especially with the statue of St. Peter situated there.

A massive square great for photos.. This is a great place for photos and we passed through it on many occasions during our visit. The weather seems to constantly change and this vast space goes from being packed to virtually empty. I would therefore keep an eye out for when those photo opportunities are at their best and snap away.
Impressive space. Large, impressive, awe-inspiring space. You feel very small when you are surrounded by the massive ornate buildings.

A giant square. Fortunately free of traffic. Admire the tall red marble monolith column, one of the world's tallest and the view around. From there you have access to the fantastic Ermitage museum. What a collection of artwork.
Great!. Huge square and everywhere you look, you see something great, like Hermitage. Grab a liitle bite from a street vendor and sit for awhile to wonder this great place.
Breathtaking. The expansiveness of it all really does boggle the mind. It is amazing when one considers that the column is just sitting in place - that there is nothing connecting it to the base.
Huge square... a lot going on. This is just a huge public square! Not much else more. It is a must visit if in Russia. But a simple walkthrough and snap a few pics will do.
Great atmosphere. We enjoyed the Palace Square more than the Red Square in Moscow. Plenty to see and a lovely atmosphere.

It's huge!. The Palace Square is just huge: it is surrounded by palaces. Unbelievably wide, you can see so many different people from all around the world walking here. I can't be sure if this square is the biggest, but it's for sure the most beautiful that I've seen in my life.
Palace Square. One of the largest squares I've visited. It is very close to the hotel where I stayed so I crossed it several times. Very impressive.

A Lovely and Elegant Ensemble. With the Winter Palace and Hermitage anchoring one side of the and the huge General Staff Building on the other, Palace Square has both symmetry and elegance. The addition of the Alexander Column, a free-standing obelisk, in the middle makes this square one of the most pleasing and impressive in Europe.
Beautiful and historical.... A must see to experience Russian heritage. Beautiful buildings and the statues will inspire you - especially if you come in the summer!
Palace Square. Very interesting and a nice place to sit and people watch on a nice sunny day sipping on a hot cup of coffee

Its a Square. Honestly, it is just a really big square that is massive. There isn't much more to it other than the winter palace is on one side which makes this quite a special place. Also, you can't help but to picture Pierce Bronson driving a tank through it like in Goldeneye.

overwhelming size.. As you enter the square you will feel the whole of St Petersburg open up. The architecture surrounding the vast paved are is pretty buy but as well decorated as some other buildings in the city. It is well worth a visit if not only for some space .

Palace Square. Huge square, took lots of pictures and took a ride with a horse. Nice to experience it once... There are also people dressed in the clothes of 18th century, gives a special feeling and atmosphere
Large open square. Spent 30 minutes here - not a lot to see apart from admiring the architecture of surrounding buildings.

Amazing place!. I walked on this area so many times! And each time, leaving narrow small streets - as if intercepts breath! And then it becomes easier to breathe. Fantastically beautiful place with rich history. Perfectly at any time years and in any weather. If you visit St. Petersburg for the first time - you need to visit this square.

Palace square. Vast space of land between the Winter Palace and Genral Administrative Staff building. In the middle of the Square is the Alexander column, the biggest single piece column in the world, not anchored to tthe ground but standing under it's own weight. Another great panoramaic view, well worth the visit, without a doubt.

Impressive Square. The square dimensions are very very large and I couldn't stop thinking of a concert gathering dozens of thousands of people taking place in this square !! The building that surround the square are quite high (the Hermitage is among them) and it's a pleasure to walk by the Alexander column.
Palace Swuare. The vastness of this space surrounded with such beautiful buildings and facades is amazine and unique.
Beautiful Open Space. A few cafes along the perimeter would help..... . . . . . . . . . .sometimes in a review less is more but trip advisor doesn't seem to think so!!!

St Petersburg Anniversary. We were lucky enough to be here for the big day and what a place to go for a free 2 hour classical concert with Maria Stefyuk, and other opera singers and the philarmonic orchestra. Stunning backdrop

no scaffolding. this year Palace Square looks beautiful as the renovation work seems to have been completed & the magnificence of the area shines through.
A new tourist information office has popped up there now . very helpful lots of brochures offers etc many languages spoken.

large square... with no activities on-going can be rather dull. If there is an event, outstanding. If there is nothing happening, it's just a large square with the statue (oft-vandalized) in the center.

very impressive square with lots of buses. We walked by many times and always stopped to take a look since there was always something going on...horse carriages, Catherine and Peter for taking photos and lots of buses.

Huge square surrounded by beautiful buildings.. The square is surrounded by the Winter Palace, Hermitage etc and is huge. When we visited parts were being cordoned off ready for the birthday celebration of the city.

Swan Lake with a new ending!. One should not leave St Pete without seeing Swan Lake and this is the one we saw....Just a step believe the Mariinsky company, this Swan Lake was enchanting, the music superb and performance stellar....However, try not to sit on the sides of the horsehoe because you do lose a good part of the stage.

You never know what will be happening here. The Palace Square is outside the Hermitage and the Winter Palace. It is one of the biggest squares in the world. I encountered some kind of military ceremony which was interesting as I freely took photos of all the shiny equipment driven by the soldiers.

A powerful place. The Russians sure know how to make a statement about the wealth and power of their history. A huge space and it must be one of the largest squares in the world. Surrounded by beautiful neoclassical buildings in every direction and overlooked by the Winter Palace, this is a majestic place. With a lovely triumphal arch on one side and the excellent Alexander Column in the centre, this is macho Russian stuff on a grand scale. The Alexander Column is the tallest granite column in the world and was so well cut, that it stands without any attachment. At some 500 tons, it would take some moving. The square is a statement of the power and wealth of Russia and it does it very well. If you have the space, the vision and the cash, this is the way to build a square - simply superb.

Lovely atmosphere. We were lucky enough to be staying just off this square, so had to walk through it many times every day. As everyone else has said it's very impressive, grand, etc. However what we really liked is the friendly atmosphere especially later in the day. Once all the tour buses departed, people were playing street hockey, roller blading, cycling, jogging. It had a much nicer feeling then and I'd recommend visiting later in the day if you can.

An impressive space. This is a huge open area -- our guide said it was the largest such square in the world -- similar to Moscow's Red Square and Beijing's Tien An Men Square. It's certainly large, so much so that it almost loses touch with the buildings that surround it.The galleries of the Hermitage are on one side, with Hermitage administrative offices and part of the Admiralty (naval administration) on the other. The arch between the latter buildings has an impressive statue, similar to that on Paris' Arc de Triomphe -- very photogenic.The obelisk in the center
Grand. Scale, scale, scale. Hugh and grand, think of the finest european architecture and then enlarge. Best to come in through the arch off Nevskiy Prospekt the first time.

imposing. Very imposing with beautiful buildings all around, a couple of nice statues ,the Monolith with the angel on top and the group on top of the general staff building. you cannot miss it if you visit the Hermitage as you exit into this square

Victory day parade. We were lucky enough to see the rehearsal for the Victory Day parade whilst here. Impressive! Stood and watched for at least a couple of hours, The size of the square alone with its past history. Good to see it is used also for different kinds of concerts.

imposing. palace sqaure takes you to the the time of cold war images on tv. imposing area where they still hold military parades on ceratin days and if you get to see that during your visit as we did then you are very lucky as its an amazing site. palace sqaure has so much history and that in itself makes it a place to visit but you can also take some pretty amazing pictures as the Winter Palace is located there.

Impressive. The sheer size of this square is amazing as well as two large buildings at both ends of it. And equally impressive Alexander column. I was lucky to witness marching bands practicing for the May holidays so it was another unique experience.

The Main Square of St. Petersburg. Architectural ensemble, which arose during the second half of XVIII - first half of XIX century.In the construction of the Admiralty fortress-yard (founded in 1704) in accordance with the requirements of war (was Northern War between Russia and Sweden) had to leave the vast open space – “glacis”, that was the way for action fortress artillery. Quite quickly the Admiralty lost battle fortress function, leaving behind only the function built warships. And “glacis” was used for warehousing and storage building ship timber, large anchors and other Admiralty supplies. From 1712 to 1717 of the “glacis” to conduct Marine market. Later the area was overgrown with grass and turned into Admiralty meadow. That is the name stuck for a place with 1736 and lasted until 1772. During the reign of Anna Ioannovna (1730-1740) by the Treasury were arranged celebrations with fireworks and festivities of the people. At the celebrations in the meadow erected amusement halls, palaces, wine fountains, roasted gigantic carcasses of bulls, which are then to be eaten by the people gave. During the reign of Elizabeth (daughter of Peter I) until the 1760’s Admiralty meadow a supportive construction site of the Imperial Winter Palace (1754-1762). In 1753, Bartolomeo Francesco Rastrelli suggested creating a central area of the Russian capital. The final version of the Winter Palace and area against him was designed by Rastrelli simultaneously. Since 1766 the area became known as the Palace square. In 1778, Catherine II commanded to build up the southern part of the square. Architect Yury Felten (he was an Rastrelli’s assistant in the construction of the Winter Palace) built the two houses, which by architect Carlo Rossi were converted to the building of the General Staff in 1819-1829. In the 1830-1834 in the center of the square by the architect Auguste Montferrand Alexander Column was erected, dedicated to Russian victories in the war with Napoleon. Figure of an Angel made by sculptor Boris Orlovsky, who is also author of sculptures Mikhail Kutuzov and Michael Barclay de Tolly, near the Kazan Cathedral. Closed the ensemble of Palace Square on the east side Guards Corps headquarters building, constructed in 1837-1843 by the architect Alexander Briullov. Fortunately only a short time (1918-1944) the square was named after revolutionist Moisei Solomonovich Uritsky, former the first chairman of the Petrograd Cheka.Throughout his history, the Palace Square was the site of military parades and festivities of the people. In Soviet times were added the workers' demonstrations (the new era demanded of decent entertainment). The most famous amusement Catherine era - Petersburg Carousel - held on the square June 16, 1766. It remembered special luxury and scope, and fully comply with the policy of Catherine II, who tried to prove to Europe that Russia is capable of a powerful civilization bedazzle any European state. Similarly, the received and the Soviet government. July 20, 1924 in the square held idea of "living chess" with the Red Army (white) and Navy (black). Played chess masters Ilya Rabinovich and Peter Romanovsky. In the post-soviet era Palace Square became the site of concerts of world celebrities: Placido Domingo (2001), Paul McCartney (2004), Joe Cocker (2005), the rock band "The Scorpions" and "The Rolling Stones" (2007), Elton John (2007), Madonna (2009).
St. - Petersburg - a beautiful city. My impressions of the tour and the city. The area is big and beautiful! It was cold. I'm cold. It is necessary to dress warmly and everything will be fine.

take some pics before entering the Hermitage. take your moments in the middle of the square, smile, and take some pictures ;-)again, you can't miss this place as it's right at the entrance of the Hermitage!
simple. It's gorgeous, right in front of the Hermitage museum (a must). It's close to Nevsky Prospekt, just a stone's throw away. If you're going to the Hermitage, you will see it. It's simple.

Palace Square tidbits. This is where the Bolsheviks gathered to storm the Winter Palace in Oct 1917. The centerpiece is, of course, the Alexander Column, most remarkable for the fact that its 156 ft tall obelisk weighs 650 tons and is "anchored" to its base only by its own weight. You can see a model of the scaffolding built to erect it at the Commandant's House at the Peter and Paul Fortress. If you're at the Square at the right time, you may see characters dressed up as Catherine II and her lover Count Orlov wandering about chatting with the tourists.

Something out of a movie. Just looking around this square you can see the power and wealth that have been part of St. Petersburg's history. Have a local explain the story about Stalin and the column to you.

A hangout and a place of visitation and lines to the Hermitage. Every visit to St Petersburg should include a visit to Palace Square and the Alexander Column. The angel, snake underfoot, changes expression with the angle of the sun and each season. Especially in winter when Jack Frost plays his games with the column and angel.

If you are into "Squares" this is one you should visit!!!. A vast open space full of history and monuments. On one side is the Hermitage, one of the world's great palaces. There are no railings or guards you can walk up to it touch it, or lean on it if you want.If you go outside of the tourist times of 9 to 6 the square is surprisingly empty which in itself gives you a feeling of something special. In the middle of the square is the Alexander Column, the largest free standing column in the world. Explore the surrounding streets that lead to the square, which are full of interestings things to see. If you are visiting outside of the Summer months do wrap up well as the wind blows right through the square and will cut you in half like a knife. Don't let this put you off, go visit and explore.

Another Concrete Wasteland. These large squares, are devoid of any plant life, to me are a waste of space. I see them in China, Russia, Romania, and even Italy. Sometimes there are events held here. In the warmer months tourists will be taking breaks and sitting here. Locals selling plastic toys and the occasional busker can be sighted. Buses can occupy the square full of tourists in the first half of the day. In former years a mudless area was needed for formal functions. While no doubt there is history that happened in this square it did not impress me but had the opposite reaction and I am no environmentalist.

Go after 8pm in the summer. The Hermitage busses are long gone. The skateboarders, in-line skaters, drunks, and police are just starting their nights. Families are out for one last evening stroll. It is poetic and lovely.

Amazing. The Palace Square is a surprise when you first see it- a vast area with the Hermitage on one side, the curved General Staff Building on the other and the Alexander Column (the highest free standing column in the world) in the centre. Plus all of the history that has taken place here (military parades, Bloody Sunday massacre etc) makes the Palace Square very special indeed.

A Square that oozes history. I took my husband to St Petersburg for his 60th birthday. We went early May 2005. I was in essence, going along for the ride, not having had any feelings one way or another about visiting Russia. That first early morning we stood in Palace Square, it was fairly quiet being a Bank Holiday, the sun was shining and we both just stood looking round. My husband just couldn't believe he was actually there in that square he had read so much about. The history that unfolded there and the architecture itself of the Winter Palace and the other buildings, just exuded an almost tangible atmosphere. It was far bigger than either or us had imagined. His dream had come true and at that moment I too was hooked on this very fascinating and enigmatic country.
